revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} There are at least two hundred and twelve detailed '''drawings by Douglas Hamilton''' of [[South India]]n [[Landscape art|landscapes]], [[game (food)|game animals]] and [[Forest management|forestry operations]]. Eighty seven of Hamilton's careful [[drawing]]s of the [[Annaimalai Hills]], [[Palani Hills]] and [[Shevaroy Hills]] are in the [[British Library]],<ref name="BLB"/> ninety six drawings were published in his autobiography, ''Records of Sport in Southern India...'' and an additional thirty one were published in ''Forests and Gardens of South India''. [[File:Douglas Hamilton and bearer cropped.jpg|thumb|Douglas Hamilton, self-portrait...107]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, His First Ibex...120.jpg|thumb|His first ibex]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, signature.jpg|thumb|400px|''Douglas Hamilton'' signature, c. 1891]] Lieutenant-Colonel [[Douglas Hamilton]] (1818 – 1892) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Presidency armies|Indian Army]] officer, gazetted to the 21st Regiment of the [[Madras Army|Madras Native Infantry]] from 1837 to 1871.<ref name="Ham">{{cite book|last=Hamilton|first=General Douglas|title=Records of sport in southern India chiefly on the Annamullay, Nielgherry and Pulney mountains, also including notes on Singapore, Java and Labuan, from journals written between 1844 and 1870|editor=Hamilton, Edward|publisher= R. H. Porter|location=London|year=1892|pages= Illustrated, photo. Frontis of the author. Numerous illustrations, some full page. 284 pages. Quarto.|oclc=4008435|url=http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/oclc/262468650?page=frame&url=%3D%3FUTF-8%3FB%3FaHR0cDovL3d3dy5hcmNoaXZlLm9yZy9kZXRhaWxzL3JlY29yZHNvZnNwb3J0aW4wMGhhbWlyaWNo%3F%3D&title=&linktype=digitalObject&detail=}}</ref> Hamilton was a well known [[forester]], [[Medical intelligence|surveyor]] and [[illustrator]] of the early British [[hill station]]s in South India and a famous [[Hunting#Modern sport hunting|sportsman]], [[Hunting#Shikar (Indian Subcontinent)|shikari]], [[big-game hunter]] and [[Trophy hunting#The hunting trophy|trophy]] collector. He was an acute observer of [[nature]] and a [[Gentleman#Modern usage|gentleman]].<ref>Hamilton, p. xxxviii</ref>
Though executed only in [[pen and ink]] or pencil, these drawings have [[artistic merit]] due to the artists skillful use of [[hatching]] and [[stippling]] to achieve [[Realism (arts)|realistic]] [[Texture (visual arts)|texture]], [[Shading#Drawing|shading]] and [[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]]. Hamilton's illustration of subjects and backgrounds that are unfamiliar to most people, creates initial interest in his drawings. His effective portrayal of actual or implied recent or future dramatic [[Action (philosophy)|action]] heightens the viewers interest in his subjects. Hamilton selected his sketches that best illustrate scenes in his writing.<ref>Hamilton, p. v.</ref> This implies there were also additional drawings, however their existence is now unknown.
==Government drawings== [[File:Douglas_Hamilton,_1870.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Douglas Hamilton, 1870, age 52]] In 1862 Colonel Hamilton was relieved of routine regimental Army duties and given a [[roving commission]] by [[Sir Charles Trevelyan, 1st Baronet|Sir Charles Trevelyan]], the Finance Minister of India and former [[Governors_Of_Madras#Governors_.28of_British_India.29|Governor]] of [[Madras Presidency]], to conduct surveys and make drawings for the Government of all the [[Hill_station#India_.28by_state.29|hill plateau]]s in Southern India that might suit as Sanitaria, or quarters for European troops. Thereafter, Douglas Hamilton was on "special duty" with the 44th Regiment, Madras Native Infantry.<ref name="PP">{{cite book|authors= Great Britain Parliament. House of Commons, Parliament, Great Britain, House of Commons|title=Parliamentary Papers|publisher= HMSO |year=1866|edition=Original from Harvard, Digitized 17 December 2007|series=Item notes: 1866|volume=:v.53|pages=69|chapter=enclosure 1. in No. 33 of the Chinchona plant into India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KxMTAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA69&lpg=RA2-PA69&dq=Hamilton+pykara+hut&source=bl&ots=pV2RdjiBPj&sig=YQG13f45PCsG_2QXBbuH-t3jUsQ&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result}}</ref>
A series of five albums of careful drawings of the [[Annaimalai Hills]], [[Palani Hills]] and [[Shevaroy Hills]] was the result of this commission. While at work on this commission he had great opportunities to follow his favorite pursuit of [[big game hunting]], and also to observe the habits of the various animals inhabiting the different districts. These well-known drawings showed him as an accurate observer and a careful draughtsman. Each series of drawings was accompanied by a [[Survey article]] describing all aspects of the district.<ref>Hamilton, p.xiii</ref> Some of his publications about these surveys include: :Lt.-Col. Douglas Hamilton, Report on the Shevaroy Hills (Madras, 1862), :Lt.-Col. Douglas Hamilton, Report on the Pulni Mountains (Madras, 1864) :Lt.-Col. Douglas Hamilton, Report on the High Ranges of the Annamullay Mountains (Madras, 1866)<ref name="Kennedy">{{cite book|last=Kennedy|first=Dane |title=The Magic Mountains Hill Stations and the British Raj|publisher=UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA PRESS|location=Berkeley · Los Angeles · Oxford|year=1996|pages=50|url=http://www.escholarship.org/editions/view?docId=ft396nb1sf&chunk.id=0&toc.depth=1&toc.id=0&brand=ucpress&query=hamilton}}</ref>
=== Albums at British Library === The [[India Office Records]] in the [http://www.bl.uk/reshelp/bldept/apac/asianprintsdrawings/infenqread/asianprintsinfo.html Asian and African Print Room] at the [[British Library]] has five albums of Hamilton's work that include eighty six drawings.<ref name="BLB">{{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/catalogues/indiaofficeselectpd/PrintandDraw.aspx|title=Prints & drawings search results|work=Prints & drawings search: "Artist: Douglas Hamilton"|publisher=The British Library Board|pages= |accessdate=2009-03-03}}</ref> These albums are: ;12 Drawings in the Shevaroy Hills - WD1351, Hamilton, Douglas (1818-1892) is an album of 12 [[pen and ink|pen and ink drawings]] of landscapes in the [[Shevaroy Hills]] made in 1861. The 24 folio volume is entitled: ''Sketches of the Shevaroy Hills by Lieut-Col. Douglas Hamilton, Madras army. 1861.'' Printed descriptions are attached to each picture. Size of the volume is 22.5 by 31.75 inches. It was deposited in the British Library on 4 June 1866.<ref>Prints & drawings: WD1351</ref> These drawings are: [[File:Waterfall Near the Village of Killayur...viii.jpg|thumb|200px|Waterfall Near the Village of Killayur...viii]] :# f.2 ‘1.(*) ''Waterfall near the village of Killeyor.'' An Englishman in the foreground. :# f.4 ‘2. ''Panoramic view from the Garden of Dr Marrett's House at Yercaud.’ An Englishman, his wife and child in the foreground. :# f.6’ 3. ''View of the Temple on the Shevaroyen.'' :# f.8 ‘4. ''Panoramic view of [[Yercaud]] from the summit of the Shevaroyen.'' :# f.10 ‘5.(*) ''The lake at Yercaud.''[[File:Douglas Hamiltom, Lake of Yercaud, Shervaroy Hills.jpg|thumb|200px|Lake of Yercaud, Shervaroy Hills...xix]] :# f.12 ‘6. ''Panoramic view of Yercaud and the Green Hills, taken from Fischer's Hill.'' Two Englishmen in the foreground. :# f.14 ‘7. ''Hill temples.’ :# f.16 ‘8. ''Panorama of the plateau of the Green Hills.'' :# f.18 ‘9. ''View of the plateau of the Green Hills.'' :# f.20 ‘10. ''View of a Malayaly village and cultivation.'' An Englishman in the foreground. :# f.22 ‘11. ''View of a Malayaly village.'' :# f.24 ‘12. ''Panoramic view of the Athoor Ghaut from the summit of the Shevaroyen.'' Two Englishmen with servants and horses in the foreground. :(*): also published in ''Records of Sport in Southern India...''
;26 Drawings in the Palni Hills - WD566, Hamilton, Douglas (1818-1892) is an album of 26 pen and ink drawings of views in the [[Palani Hills Wildlife Sanctuary and National Park|Palni Hills]]. This 60 folio volume of views in the Palni Hills was made in 1862, with printed titles and descriptions and some drawings inscribed with titles in pencil. Size of the volume is 20 by 25 inches. It was deposited c. 1866.<ref>Prints & drawings: WD566</ref> These drawings are: [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Pillar rocks.jpg|thumb|200px|View of the Pillar Rocks in Kodaikanal, Tamil Nadu, India]] :# f.3 ‘1. ''View of the Entrance to the Hill Village of Pullangee.'' :# f.5 ‘2. ''Distant view of Pulni Mountains.'' :# f.7 ‘3. ''View of the higher Pulnis.'' :# f.9 ‘4. ''View in the [[Periyakulam|Perreakolum]] Pass.'' :# f.11 5. ''Another view of the Periyakulam Pass.'' Hamilton and his horse in the foreground. :# f.13 ‘6. ''View in the valley of Perrumbookarnal.'' Hamilton and his gun-bearer in the foreground stalking [[ibex]]. Reproduced: ‘Records of sport,’ plate xv. :# f.15 ‘7. ''View of the Settlement of [[History of Kodaikanal|Kudaikarnal]].'' :# f.17 ‘8. ''Distant View of Kudaikarnal.'' :# f.21 ‘9. ''Panorama of the Plateau in the Neighbourhood of Kudaikarnal.'' Pillar Rocks and Hamilton with servant and dog pursuing a stag. :# f.23 ‘10.(*) ''View of the Pillar Rocks.'' :# f.25 ‘11. ''View of the great cave at the Pillar Rocks.'' :# f.27 ‘12. ''View to the South West beyond the Pillar Rocks.'' Deer. :# f.29 ‘13. ''View of the Gundair and [[Poombarai|Pombarry]] valleys.'' A herd of bison in the foreground. :# f.31 ‘14. ''View of [[Vilpatti|Vilputty]],'' 3 miles N.E. of Kodalkanal. :# f.35 ‘15. ''Panorama of 'the Plateau of Poortoor.’ :# f.37 ‘16. ''View of Pullangee.’ :# f.43 ‘18. ''View of the Entrance to the Village of Pombarry.'' :# f.45 ‘19. ''A Street in the hill village of Pombarry.'' :# f.47 ‘20. ''View of 'the Pombarry Valley.’ :# f.49 ‘21. ''Wooded Valley between Kodaikarnal and Pombarry.'' Deer in the foreground. :# f.51 ‘22. ''Distant View of Kokul.'' A villager grazing cows in the foreground. :# f.53 ‘23. ''View of [[Kukkal|Kokul Village]].'' :# f.55 ‘24. ''Distant View of the Hills near Ettoor or the Eight Villages.'' Hamilton with his sketch-book, camp chair and two attendants. :# f.57 ‘25. 'View of the entrance to the village of [[Mannavanur]].'' :# f.59 ‘26. ''View of Perumal Mullay and the lower Pulnis.'' Hamilton looking through his field-glasses; a gun-bearer and dead deer in the foreground.
;17 Drawings in the Palni Hills - WD1350, Hamilton, Douglas (1818-1892); is an album of 17 pen and ink drawings of landscapes in the Palni Hills, 1862 (35 folios), Volume entitled: ''Sketches of the Pulni Mountains.'' Printed descriptions are attached to each picture and there are pencil descriptions on the sketches. Size of the volume is 22.5 by 31.75 inches, deposited c. 1866.<ref>Prints & drawings: WD1350</ref> These drawings are: :# f.2 Frontispiece. ''The Devil's Gap.'' [[Bodinayakanur|Bodinalkenur]] Pass. :# f.5’ 1. ''Panorama of the High Range of the Pulnis from the summit of the Perumal mullay.'' :# f.7 ‘2. ''View from the high ground west of the settlement of Kudaikarnal.'' :# f.9 ‘3. ''View of Perumal Mullay from the encampment.'' :# f.11 ‘4. ''Panorama overlooking the 'Cumbum Valley'.'' :# f.13 ‘5. ''The Pillar Rocks.'' :# .15 ‘6. ''Bird's Eye view of the ancient lake'' near Kodaikanal. :# f.17 ‘7. ''View of the ancient lake from near the breach'' in the embankment. Near Kodaikanal. :# f.19 ‘8. ''The breached embankment.'' :# f.21 ‘9. ''View of the boundary ridge dividing the Pulnis’ ‘from [[Travancore]].'' Englishmen shooting bison in foreground. :# f.23 ‘10. ''Village on the lower Pulnis.'' :# f.25 ‘11. ''View near Perryoor on the lower Pulnis.'' :# f.27 ‘12. ''View of the lower Pulnis.'' :# f.29 ‘13. ''View of the entrance to the village of [[Periyar (village)|Perryoor]].'' :# f.31 ‘14. ''View on the lower Pulnis.'' :# f.33 ‘15. ''The Pulnis from the village of [[Palani|Pulni]].'' Villagers in the foreground. :# f.35 Vignette.'' Mountain antelope and Ponjola Hill.''
;17 Drawings in the Anaimalai Hills - WD567, Hamilton, Douglas (1818-1892) is an album of 17 pen and ink drawings of views in the [[Anaimalai Hills]] (Cochin and Madras) 1863. European school / British school, (30 folios) 1863, with printed titles and descriptions. All signed: ‘D. Hamilton delt.’ Size of the volume is 20.75 by 14.5 inches. It was deposited c. 1866.<ref>Prints & drawings: WD567</ref> These drawings are: :# ff.2-4 ‘1. ''Panorama of the Anamallay Mountains from the village of Anamallay.'' Khaders in the foreground. :# f.5 ‘2. ''The Foot of the Poonachy Pass.'' :# f.5 ‘3. ''Encampment at Poonachy.'' :# f.7 ‘4. ''Lower valley of the Tooracoodoo.'' :# f.9 ‘5. ''Our first view of the 'Tungachee'.'' An Englishman in the foreground. :# f.11 ‘6. ''The 'Tungachee' and 'Ukka'.'' :# f.13 ‘7. ''Khader Rattan Chain for collecting honey.'' :# f.15 ‘8. ''Waterfall at foot of the 'Tungachee'.'' :# f.17 ‘9. ''Ancient Cromlech. Lower valley of the Tooracoodoo.'' :# f.18 '10. ''Primitive bridge of the Khaders.'' An English party in the foreground. :# f.19 ‘11. ''Haystack rock. Rattan Chain.'' :# f.21 ‘12. ''The 'Tungachee' from our encampment.'' :# ff.23,24 ‘13. ''High range from our Encampment.'' Villagers and [[Indian elephant|elephants]] in the foreground. :# f.26 ‘14. ''View in Michael's Valley.'' :# f.28 ‘15. ''Water-fall in Michael's Valley.'' :# f, 16. ''Gorge of the Tooracoodoo.'' :# f.29 ‘17. ''High range from the lower valley of the Tooracoodoo.'' Englishmen and elephants in the foreground.
;15 Drawings in the Anaimalai Hills - WD568, Hamilton, Douglas (1818-1892); is an album of 15 pen and ink drawings (33 folios) of views in the Anaimalai Hills (Cochin and Madras). 1863, with printed titles and descriptions. (Inscribed on [[Endpaper|fly leaf]]: ‘India Museum, received from public deposit on 4th June 1866’). Size of the volume is 22 by 28.5 inches.<ref>Prints & drawings: WD568</ref> These drawings are: :# 2 Frontispiece. ‘'Cascade in Michael's Valley.'’ Dogs pursuing a stag. :# f.5 ‘1. ''Outline panorama of Michael's Valley looking west.'' Hamilton and an attendant stalking ibex. :# f.7 ‘2. ''Bird's eye view of Michael's Valley looking west''. Taken from the hill, Parli Mulai. :# f.10 ‘3. ''Panoramic view of Michael's Valley looking east.'' Ibex in foreground. :# f.12 ‘4. ''View of the Upper or Western portion of the large swamp in Michael's Valley.'' [[Gaur|Bison]] in foreground. :# f.14 ‘5. '' View of the lower portion of the large swamp in Michael's Valley.'' Elephants and [[Sambar (deer)|sambur]]. :# f.16 ‘6. ''Water-fall below Michael's Valley.'' Ibex. :# f.18 ‘7. ''View of the Eastern Plateaux'' referred to in sketch No. 3. Ibex in foreground. :# f.20 ‘8. ''View of Coomarikul Plateau.'' Ibex and bison. :# f.22 ‘9. ''Encampment at the lower end of Michael's Valley.'' Hamilton returning from shikar with two attendants'' :# f.24 ‘10. ''View between Michael's Valley and Coomarikul Plateau.'' Bison grazing :# f.26 ‘11. ''View looking towards the valley of the Toracuddu River.'' :# f.29 ‘12. ''View across the upper or western end of Michael's Valley looking south.'' Hamilton and an attendant stalking sambur. :# f.31 ‘13. ''Panoramic view of the great plateau and the Arney Moodie Mountain looking west.'' [[Leopard]] in foreground and ibex grazing. :# f.33 [[Vignette (graphic design)|Vignette]]. ''Pooliar village and figures.''
== ''Records of Sport'' == [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Records of Sport in Southern India.jpg|thumb|200px|Leather cover of ''Records of Sport in Southern India...'']]Hamilton's brother Edward was the editor of Douglas Hamilton's 1892 autobiography, ''"Records of Sport in Southern India, Chiefly on the Annamullay, Nielgherry and Pulney Mountains, also Including Notes on Singapore, Java and Labuan, ..."''. It is about "years long gone by when the [[muzzle loader]], with all its drawbacks, was the chief weapon in use."<ref name="Ham"/> All ninety five drawings in ''Records of Sport...'' (with the exception of three) were taken from his sketch books. All scenes illustrated in these drawings are based on the actual hunting experiences of Colonel Hamilton described in full detail in his Autobiography.
Those he drew in [[Indian ink]] were transferred as [[facsimile]]s by means of [[Etching|photo-etching]]. The others, sketched in pencil, were copied by Mr. J. T. Smit with such care and accuracy that the touch, as well as the spirit, of the original sketches was fully retained. The three plates of the two species of [[Bustard|florican]] and of the [[jungle cat]] are from drawings made expressly for ''Records of Sport'' by Mr. Smit. Several types of [[Big-game hunting|big game]] are the primary subject of most of these Drawings. Only a few of the drawings overlap with those in the India Office collection. He also drew several landscapes of [[Singapore]], [[Java]] and [[Labuan]] during his visit there in 1848. The Drawings are:
===Galleries of 95 drawings=== :- Portrait of Major Douglas Hamilton, 1870. . . Frontispiece [[File:Douglas Hamilton, preface art.jpg|right|400px]] :- Preface art...v: [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Bababooden hills, falls.jpg|thumb|Upper falls near Muddikull, Bababooden hills...xxxvi]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton,Valley of Perumbookarnal, Pulney mountains...xv.jpg|thumb|Valley of Perumbookarnal, Pulney mountains...xv]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Cheetah stalking Antelope...910.jpg|thumb|Cheetah stalking Antelope...10]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Mungoose and Cobra...jpg|thumb|Mungoose and Cobra...28]] PREFACE #The Pillar Rocks, Pulney Mountains . . . xiii #Water Fall near the Village of Killiyur . . .viii #View in the Valley of Perumbookarnal, Pulney Mountains...xv #Lake of Yercaud, Shervaroy Hills ...xviii #The Upper Falls, near Muddikull, Bababoopen Hills...xxxvi CHAPTER I. - Shooting Antelope # Stalking Antelope with Pony...1 #Spearing the Antelope...5 #The [[Bengal fox|Silver Grey Fox]] (Canis bengalensis)...7 #''Oh, Great King, Don't be Angry''...9 #[[Asiatic cheetah|Cheeta]] Stalking [[Blackbuck|Antelope]]...10 #The Kill...11 #The Mountain Antelope...14 <gallery> Image:Douglas Hamilton, Stalking Antelope with Pony...1.jpg|Stalking Antelope with Pony...1 Image:Douglas hamilton, Spearing antelope.jpg|Spearing Antelope...5 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Canis bengalensis...7.jpg|Wild Dog, Canis bengalensis...7 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Oh, Great King, Don't be Angry...9.jpg|Oh, Great King, Don't be Angry...9 </gallery> [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Lesser Florican...jpg|thumb|Lesser Florican...36]] CHAPTER II. - Wolves, Wild Dogs, Boars, Mongoose, Small Game Shooting #Wolves Watching Antelope...19 #Wild Dogs ([[Dhole|Cuon rutilans]])...25 #[[Mongoose|Mungoose]] and [[Cobra]]...28 #Rather a Stopper...31 #A Brave Boar...33 #The [[Lesser florican|Lesser Florikin]] (Syphcolides auritus)...36 #The [[Bengal florican|Bengal Florican]] (Spyheoides bengaleiuis)...36 <gallery> Image:Douglas Hamilton, Wolves Watching Antelope...19.jpg|Wolves Watching Antelope...19 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Wild Dogs...25.jpg|Wild Dogs, (Cuon rutilans)...25 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Rather a Stopper...31.jpg|Rather a Stopper...31 Image:Douglas Hamilton, The Bengal Florican...36.jpg|Bengal Florican...36 </gallery> CHAPTER III. - Sporting Trip to the Dandilly Forest #The Bungalow, Dandilly Forest...39 [[File:Douglas hamilton, Meeting Tiger.jpg|thumb|Unexpected Meeting...50]] #"I Just saw His Head and Horns"...44 #"Emam Took up the Track"...47 #An Unexpected Meeting...50 [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Curious Hat of the Rusa Deer in Java...jpg|thumb|Curious Hat of the Rusa Deer in Java...89]] [[File:Stephen Douglas, "He was Upon Me at Once"...jpg|thumb|"He was Upon Me at Once"...104]] CHAPTER IV. - Singapore, Java and Labuan #The Wart Hog of Java ([[Sus verrucosus]])...59 #The [[Semeru|Smero]] from [[Papar, Sabah|Paparawang]]...62 #Birdseye View of the Crater of the [[Mount Bromo|Bromo]]...68 #Outline of the Smeroe and the Bromo...68 #Lake of Ranio Clakka...72 #Principal Figure in the Temple of Sookoo...77 #Stone Slabs in the Temple of Sookoo, showing the manufacture of the [[Kris]]s ....78 . to face #After Deer, [[Bandung|Bandoeng]]...84 #Curious Hat of the [[Javan rusa|Rusa Deer]] in Java...89 #The Big Boar of [[Labuan]] ([[Sus barbatus]])...95 #Nests of a Diminutive Bee found at Labuan...96 CHAPTER V. - [[Sloth bear|Bears]] #He tried hard to get at us through the Bamboos...99 #"He was upon me at once"...104 #"I didn't do it, Ma!"...107 #I could Hear the Bones Breaking...110 [[File:Douglas hamilton, Nilgiri Tahr.jpg|thumb|Nilgiri Tahr pair...111]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Niligiri Tahr, Annaimalai.jpg|thumb|Ibex Hills, Annaimalai...117]] CHAPTER VI. - [[Nilgiri tahr|Ibex]] Shooting on the Nielgherries, Annamullais, and Pulnies #The Ibex (The Nielgherry Wild Goat), Male and Female...111 #The Ibex Hills, Annamullies...117 #My First Ibex...120 #The Hut, Pykara...122 #The Old Saddle-back...124 #I take off my Shoes...127 #A Close Shave...129 #The Ibex Stalker...135 <gallery> Image:Douglas Hamilton, The Old Saddleback...jpg|The Old Saddleback...124 Image:Douglas Hamilton, I Take Off My Shoes...127.jpg|I Take Off My Shoes...127 Image:Douglas Hamilton, A Close Shave...129.jpg|A Close Shave...129 Image:Douglas Hamilton, The Ibex Stalker...jpg|The Ibex Stalker..135 </gallery> CHAPTER VII. - [[Indian elephant|Elephant]]s [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Elephant shot.jpg|thumb|First Shot at the Great Tusker...159]] [[File:Death of Tusker.jpg|thumb|Death of the Great Tusker...160]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, 5 tigers seen.jpg|thumb|What I saw...202]] #The Knowing Old Engineer...142 #Diagram for Elephant Shots...145 #I try to drive him Home...149 #Charging a Bull Bison, 20 September 1856...151 #The Tables Turned...154 #We held on like "Grim Death"...154 #Help ! Help ! !...155 #We Secure him at last...155 #Heels over Head...157 #The First Shot at the Great Tusker...159 #The Death of the Great Tusker of Hassanoor...160 #"BAFFLED" (for description see Chapter VIII)...164 [[File:Douglas Hamilton, I Could Have Slapped His Face...220.jpg|thumb|I Could Have Slapped His Face...220]] [[File:The Jungle Cat (Felis chaus)...223.jpg|thumb|The Jungle Cat (Felis chaus)...223]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, My last leopard, Feb. 8, 1870.jpg|thumb|His last leopard, 8 February 1870...235]] CHAPTER VIII. - [[Bengal tiger|Tiger]]s, Leopards etc. #Tigers and Sambur...173 #The Cheeky Rascal...185 #A Most Magnificent Bound...188 #The Vultures Bring Him Out...189 #Rather a Surprise...191 #The Mid-Day Siesta...192 #I staring at him, and He Glaring and Growling...197 #He stopped to look at me...200 #What I saw one Morning...202 #He stood to Listen205 #Face to Face...209 #I could have Slapped its Face...220 #The Jungle Cat (Felis chaus)...223 #It will Sit and Watch on a Crag...224 #The Black Leopard...225 #The Black Leopard— His Death...226 #The Leopard's Ride...228 #Leopard on Bough...232 #My Last Leopard...235 <gallery> Image:Douglas Hamilton, Baffled...164.jpg|Baffled...164 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Mid-Day Siesta...jpg|Mid-Day Siesta...192 Image:Douglas Hamilton, I staring at him, and He Glaring and Growling...197.jpg|I staring at him, and He Glaring and Growling...197 Image:He stood to Listen, I Looking the Other Way...jpg|He stood to Listen, I Looking the Other Way...205 </gallery> [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Attacked by bison.jpg|thumb|Not the Pleasantest Moment..., 30 Aug. 1856...248]] CHAPTER IX. - The [[Gaur|Bison of Southern India]] [[File:The Unheeded Warning...jpg|thumb|The Unheeded Warning...262]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, The Axis or Spotted Deer...jpg|thumb|The Axis or Spotted Deer...277]] #Head of a Bull Bison...236 #Skull and Horns of Bison...238 #I Plunged My Hunting Knife Into His Side...243 #A Big Bull Bison staring at me...245 #A Tall Shot...246 #Not the pleasantest Moment of my Life...248 #A dead Bull...248 <gallery> Image:Douglas Hamilton, Plunge knife in bison.jpg|I Plunged My Hunting Knife Into His Side...243 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Head of bull bison.jpg|Head of bull bison...236 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Dimensions of Bison horns.jpg|Dimensions of Bison horns...238 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Axis Deer.jpg|Axis deer, Trophy Antlers...279 </gallery> CHAPTER X. - #''The Sambur'' buck and doe...252[[File:Douglas hamilton, Sambar bucks & does.jpg|thumb|Sambar Bucks and Does...252]] #Head and Horns of the big Antler Stag...258 #The Unheeded Warning...262 #His Last Leap...265 #Puzzled...268 #Snob and the Stag...269 #"Now Bounding into the Air"...271 #The Deer Stalker...278 #The Axis or [[Axis deer|Spotted Deer]]...279 #The Jungle Sheep...280
==''Forests and Gardens of South India''== In 1861, 13 plates and 17 figures of drawings by Douglas Hamiton were published in [[Hugh Francis Cleghorn#Forests and gardens of South India|''The Forests and Gardens of South India'']] written by his friend and co-conservator [[Hugh Francis Cleghorn]]. Several of the drawings were [[lithograph]]ed by Mr. W. H. Macfarane, Edinburgh. Most of the drawings were technical illustrations of forestry operations, though some depicted landscapes of forested areas.<ref name="Cleghorn">{{cite book|last=Cleghorn|first=Hugh Francis Clarke |title=The Forests and Gardens of South India |publisher=W. H. Allen|location=London|year= 1861|edition=Original from the University of Michigan, Digitized 10 Feb 2006|oclc= 301345427|url=http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/oclc/301345427?page=frame&url=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D_ZbC9FY1JqIC%26checksum%3D374d90c92770a514a51708f07461f0b3&title=&linktype=digitalObject&detail=}}</ref> These drawings are: [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Foot of the Poonachy Pass - Crossing the Torakudu River.jpg|thumb|400px|IX- Foot of the Poonachy Pass, Crossing the Torakudu River...290]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, plate 7, Ox Cart.jpg|thumb|200px|I- Usual way of loading a country cart...70]] ;Plates: :# Forest Chart, facing title page. :# I. The usual way of loading a [[Bullock cart|country cart]] with a squared beam. . . .facing 70 :# II. Mischief caused by the [[Xylocopa|carpenter-bees]] in a log of [[Terminalia chebula|Chebulai]]...facing 71 :# III. [[Bamboo]] & The formation of a ghat in lieu of the rude timber slip. . . . facing 75 :# IV. [[Teak|Teak Tree]]. . . . facing 107 :# V. Teak. .. .facing 108 :# VI. Natives Carrying Fuel . . .facing 146 :# VII. Woman sitting . . .290 :# VIII. Panorama of mountain range from this village, showing the eastern aspect ('North Latitude 10' 27". East Longitude 77.') {{coord|10|27|N|77|0|E}}. . . facing 289 :# IX. Foot of the Poonachy Pass, Crossing the Torakudu River. . .290 :# X. Ancient [[Dolmen#Asia|Cromlech]].. . 292 :# XI. gives a good outline of the Tangachi and Akka Mountains. . .292 :# XII. Rattan Chain for Collecting Honey (partial image) . . .facing 294 :# XIII. Gorge of the Toracodu River. . . 296 <gallery> Image:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Carpenter Bees.jpg|II- Mischief caused by Carpenter-bees...71 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Bamboo.jpg|III- Bamboo & The Formation of a Ghat...75 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Teak tree.jpg|IV- Teak tree...107 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Teak tree, A.jpg|V- Teak tree...108 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, plate IX- Carrying Firewood.jpg|VI- Natives Carrying Fuel...146 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Panorama of mountain range from this village.png|VIII- Panorama of mountain range from this village...289 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, X- Ancient Cromlech.jpg|X. Ancient Cromlech. . . 292 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Alan,XI- Tangachi and Akka Mountains.jpg|XI- Tangachi and Akka Mountains...292 </gallery> ;Figures [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Ferry boat.png|thumb|fig. 3. Ferry Boat...41]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Fig. 6. Natives using the Saw..png|thumb|Fig. 6. Natives using the Saw...69]] [[File:Douglas Hamilton, Alan, Fig. 13. Vertical Section of Kiln.png|thumb|fig. 13. Vertical Section of Kiln...284]] :# fig. 1. Drag holes in Log...3 :# fig. 2. 'V' shapes incisions in Kino tree...13 :# fig. 3. Ferry Boat...41 :# fig. 4. Showing Radial and Concentric Splits...65 :# fig. 5. Pile of Wood raised on Bricks...65 :# fig. 6. Natives using the Saw...69 :# fig. 7. Windward - Leeward...145 :# fig. 8. Tap Root...175 :# fig. 9. Avenue Trees Protected. From Du Breuil, ''Court d'Arboriculture'', illustrates the manner in which avenue-trees are protected in the Boulevards of Paris....198 :# fig. 10. Forked Stick...283 :# fig. 11. stacked Billets...284 :# fig. 12. Section of one-half of the Kiln...284 :# fig. 13. Vertical Section of Kiln...284 :# fig. 14. Horizontal Section of Kiln...286 :# fig. 15, Kiln After Thirty-six Hours...286 :# fig. 16. Vertical Section of Charcoal Pit, with Vent Holes and Covering of Sod...287 :# fig. 17. Kiln Dug Out the Side of a Hill...288
==Self-portraits== Hamilton often portrayed himself in his drawings. He is shown at different times with [[sideburns|mutton chop sideburns]] or a [[full beard]]. He is almost always shown holding his rifle and facing to the right. These self-portraits are cropped from drawings in ''Records of Sport...'': <gallery> Image:Stepheb Douglas, Portrait, He was upon Me at Once...jpg|Douglas Hamilton, He was upon Me at Once, 1844 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Portrait, Heels over Head, 1856...jpg|Douglas Hamilton, Heels over Head, 1856 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Portrait, Tables Turned, 1856...jpg|Douglas Hamilton, Tables Turned, 1856 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Portrait, Attacked by bison.jpg|Douglas Hamilton, Attacked by bison, 1856 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Killeyor portrait.jpg|Douglas Hamilton at Killeyor, 1861 Image:Douglas Hamilton with Sir Victor Brooke after Death of Tusker, 1863.jpg|Douglas Hamilton with Sir Victor Brooke after Death of Tusker, 1863 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Portrait, He stopped to look at me...jpg|Douglas Hamilton, He stopped... 1867 Image:Douglas Hamilton, Portrait, I Could Have Slapped His Face...jpg|Douglas Hamilton, I Could Have Slapped His Face. </gallery>

{{Ebola virus disease epidemic}} In 2014, '''Ebola virus disease in Spain''' occurred due to two patients with cases of the disease contracted during the [[Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa]]; they were [[medical evacuation|medically evacuated]].<ref name=spa/><ref name=spa1/> A failure in infection control in the treatment of the second patient led to an isolated infection of Ebola virus disease in a health worker in Spain itself. The health worker survived her Ebola infection, and has since been declared infection-free.<ref name=ABC2014 />
== Initial medevac cases == {{Main|West African Ebola virus epidemic}} On 5 August 2014, the [[Brothers Hospitallers of St. John of God]] confirmed that Brother Miguel Pajares, who had been volunteering in Liberia, had become infected. He was evacuated to Spain on 6 August 2014, and subsequently died on 12 August.<ref name="spa">{{cite web |title=Muere el religioso español Miguel Pajares a causa del ébola |url=http://www.rtve.es/noticias/20140812/muere-religioso-espanol-miguel-pajares-causa-del-ebola/991420.shtml |publisher=RTVE |date=12 August 2014 |accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref>
On 21 September it was announced that Brother Manuel García Viejo, another Spanish citizen who was medical director at the [[San Juan de Dios Hospital]] in [[Lunsar]], had been evacuated to Spain from Sierra Leone after being infected with the virus. His death was announced on 25 September.<ref name="spa1">{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/ebola-outbreak-spanish-missionary-manuel-garcia-viejo-dies-deadly-virus-madrid-1467233|title=Ebola Outbreak: Spanish Missionary Manuel Garcia Viejo Dies of Deadly Virus in Madrid|date=25 September 2014|accessdate=25 September 2014|work=International Business Times}}</ref> Both of these cases were treated at the [[Hospital Carlos III]] in Madrid.<ref>{{cite web|title=Una auxiliar de enfermería que atendió al misionero fallecido García Viejo, contagiada de ébola|url=http://www.elmundo.es/madrid/2014/10/06/5432bb62e2704e347a8b4577.html|publisher=El Mundo|accessdate=6 October 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref>
=== Medical personnel infection === [[File:Excalibur (24).jpg|thumb|left|Protest against euthanasia of Romero Ramos' pet dog]] In October 2014, María Teresa Romero Ramos, an [[healthcare assistant|auxiliary nurse]] who had cared for Manuel García Viejo<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2014/1006/650268-ebola/|title=Spanish nurse tests positive for Ebola|publisher=RTE|date=7 October 2014}}</ref> at the Hospital Carlos III had become unwell and on 6 October tested positive for Ebola at her local hospital in [[Alcorcón]], the [[Hospital Universitario Fundación Alcorcón]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/10/08/world/europe/ebola-spain/|title=Hospital worker: Spaniard exposed in ER for 8 hours after positive Ebola test|publisher=CNN|author1=Greg Botelho |author2=Laura Smith-Spark |author3=Laura Perez Maestro |date=8 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Nurse 'infected with Ebola' in Spain|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-29514920|accessdate=6 October 2014|agency=BBC}}</ref><ref name=MinderNYT9Oct/> A second test confirmed the diagnosis,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cadenaser.com/sociedad/articulo/enfermera-ingresada-alcorcon-da-positivo-ebola/csrcsrpor/20141006csrcsrsoc_5/Tes|title=La enfermera ingresada en Alcorcón da positivo por ébola -- La segunda prueba ha dado positivo y confirma el diagnóstico |publisher=Cadena Ser|date=6 October 2014}}</ref> making this the first confirmed case of Ebola transmission outside Africa. Following testing, she was transferred to the [[Hospital Carlos III]] in Madrid for treatment.<ref>{{cite web|title=La segunda enfermera ingresada da negativo en la prueba del virus|url=http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/2014-10-07/la-segunda-enfermera-ingresada-da-negativo-en-la-prueba-del-virus_229489/|date=2014-10-07|publisher=El Confidencial|language=Spanish}}</ref>
As of October 7, 50 contacts were being monitored, with 7 kept in isolation at the Hospital Carlos III, and an investigation was under way.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/08/world/europe/after-its-first-ebola-case-spain-seeks-to-prevent-spread-of-virus.html|title=Demands for an Explanation Grow After a Nurse in Spain Contracts Ebola|publisher=New York Times|date=2014-10-07|author=Raphael Minder}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/World/News/More-health-workers-hospitalised-in-Spain-Ebola-scare-20141009|title=More health workers hospitalised in Spain Ebola scare|work=News24}}</ref>
On 7 October, Madrid's regional government got a court order to euthanize Romero's pet dog, Excalibur, concerned that it posed a risk as a [[reservoir host]].<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/09/science/ebola-dog-excalibur-nurse-spain.html</ref> By the afternoon there were over 30 animal rights activists who had barricaded the apartment to prevent officials from removing the dog. A number of online petitions were started rallying to save the dog, garnering hundreds of thousands of indications of support. Ramos' quarantined husband, Javier, called on a veterinarian radio show host, and recorded a video appeal, for help to save his dog. On 8 October, Spanish authorities removed, sedated and euthanized the dog and arranged for the safe disposal of its remains.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/World/News/Spanish-Ebola-nurses-pet-dog-put-down-20141008|title=Spanish Ebola nurse's pet dog put down|work=News24|accessdate=11 October 2014}}</ref>
On 9 October the Spanish health ministry quarantined three more people.<ref name=MinderNYT9Oct>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/10/world/europe/ebola-spain-nurse-hospital.html|title=Spain Quarantines 3 More Over Ebola|author=Raphael Minder|date=9 October 2014|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> The health authorities announced that Maria Teresa Romero Ramos' condition had worsened significantly.<ref name=minder9octworsened>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/10/world/europe/ebola-spain-nurse-hospital.html|title=Condition of Spanish Nurse With Ebola Worsens, Officials Say|author=Raphael Minder|date=9 October 2014|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> On October 12, she began to show some improvement. According to one report, the improvement may be attributed to Romero's having received the experimental drug [[ZMab]] which is similar to [[ZMapp]], which has been used to treat several Ebola patients. However, according to information released by Spain's Centre for Health and Emergency Alerts, the nurse did not receive ZMab due to concerns over possible side-effects.<ref name="experintal_zmap_1">{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/health/ebola-infected-spanish-nurse-improving-health-source-article-1.1970896|title=Ebola-infected Spanish nurse improving after dose of experimental drug ZMapp: health source |publisher=NEW YORK DAILY NEWS|date=October 11, 2014|accessdate=October 16, 2014}}</ref><ref name="experintal_zmap">{{cite news|title=Public Health Agency gives Spain, Norway ZMapp-like drug to treat Ebola cases|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/health/public-health-agency-gives-spain-norway-zmapp-like-drug-to-treat-ebola-cases-1.2053402|publisher=The Local Europe|date=16 October 2014 |accessdate=16 October 2014}}</ref> Romero, however, was given the experimental antiviral drug [[Favipiravir]], and it was reported that the dosages used were much higher than those used in the treatment of other patients.<ref>http://www.abc.es/sociedad/20141024/abci-ebola-dosis-antiviral-teresa-201410241656.html</ref>
Medical staff in Madrid protested about the lack of effective protective equipment and safety precautions.<ref name=minder9octworsened/> It was reported on October 17 that all the other people suspected of being infected in Spain had tested negative for the Ebola virus.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/17/two-suspected-ebola-cases-spain-test-negative-disease|title=All four suspected Ebola cases in Spain test negative for the disease|date=17 October 2014|publisher=The Guardian|author=Ashifa Kassam}}</ref>
On October 20 it was announced that Teresa Romero had tested negative for the Ebola virus,<ref name=ABC2014>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-10-20/spanish-nurse-infected-with-ebola-no-longer-has-virus/5825720|title=Ebola crisis: Tests show Spanish nurse Teresa Romero no longer has the virus|publisher = ABC News|date= 20 October 2014}}</ref> suggesting she may have cleared the virus from her system. On November 1, it was announced that she was Ebola-free, and had been moved out of the isolation ward into a normal hospital bed to finish the process of recuperation from her illness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/spanish-woman-cured-ebola-moves-normal-room-26624899|title=Spanish Woman Cured of Ebola Moves to Normal Room|author=Harold Heckle|date=1 November 2014|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> The WHO declared Spain Ebola-free on 2 December, 42 days after Teresa Romero was shown to be free of Ebola on 21 October.<ref name ="Spain_Ebola_outbreak_2_Dec">{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/spain-ebola-free-nurse-recovery-27300284|title=WHO Says Spain Ebola-Free Following Nurse Recovery|date=2 December 2014|accessdate=2 December 2014|publisher=ABC News}}</ref>
== 2018 prototype vaccine == In July 2018, a Spanish team from the [[:es:Hospital 12 de Octubre|October 12 Hospital]] in [[Madrid]] announced the discovery of an [[antibody]] and the development of a prototype vaccine against five strains of Ebola, including the most common and deadliest.<ref>https://www.thelocal.es/20180712/spanish-researchers-develop-five-strain-vaccine-ebola</ref><ref>https://www.euroweeklynews.com/news/on-euro-weekly-news/spain-news-in-english/1473157-vaccine-for-killer-ebola-virus-being-developed-by-spanish-researchers</ref><ref>https://www.redaccionmedica.com/autonomias/madrid/el-12-de-octubre-descubre-unicornio-el-anticuerpo-contra-el-ebola--3299</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last1=Rodríguez-Vega|first1=Beatriz|last2=Amador|first2=Blanca|last3=Ortiz-Villalobos|first3=Aranzazu|last4=Barbero|first4=Javier|last5=Palao|first5=Angela|last6=Avedillo|first6=Caridad|last7=Alcami|first7=Margarita|last8=García-Benito|first8=Pa|last9=Fernandez-Sanchez|first9=Aranzazu|last10=Perez-Sales|first10=Pau|last11=Bayón|first11=Carmen|last12=Cebolla|first12=Susana|last13=Ortiz|first13=Maria Fe Bravo|title=The Psychosocial Response to the Ebola Health Emergency: Experience in Madrid, Spain|journal=Clinical Infectious Diseases|date=15 June 2015|volume=60|issue=12|pages=1866–1867|doi=10.1093/cid/civ173|url=http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/60/12/1866.long|accessdate=15 July 2016|language=en|issn=1058-4838|pmid=25737372}} {{Ebola}}

revision.text:
The '''Ecclesia Athletic Association''' (EAA) was an organization founded by [[Eldridge Broussard]] in 1975, with the stated mission of helping children escape the dangers of [[Downtown Los Angeles|inner-city Los Angeles]] through strict discipline and [[athletic training]]. In 1987, the group moved from its headquarters in the [[Watts, Los Angeles|Watts]] neighborhood of Los Angeles to [[Sandy, Oregon]]. The group sometimes attracted accusations that it was a [[cult]], often from neighbors or the family of members inside the group.<ref name=":1" /> Broussard publicly denied the label, including in 1984 and in a 1988 appearance on the [[The Oprah Winfrey Show]].<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-10-20/local/me-5471_1_fatal-beating|title=Ecclesia Children Saw Fatal Beating, Oregon D.A. Says|last=Rarick|first=Ethan|date=1988-10-20|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
The EAA became defunct in October 1988 after the death of Eldridge's daughter, Dayna Broussard, prompted the removal of the remaining 53 children in the organization's care and an investigation into the group. The investigation found that the children were subject to extreme fitness training and physical punishments, including [[Flagellation|floggings]]. Four EAA staff members were convicted of manslaughter, while Broussard and seven others were charged with child slavery by the Federal government. Broussard died before the trial, while the other seven pleaded guilty to lesser charges.
== Founding == The Ecclesia Athletic Association (EAA) was founded in the [[Watts, Los Angeles|Watts]] neighborhood of [[Los Angeles]] in 1975 as a sister organization to the Watts Christian Center, a church.<ref name="LAT">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-09-06/news/mn-1749_1_cult-leader-broussard|title=Indicted Cult Leader Broussard Dies: Commune: Ex-Watts minister faced charges of enslaving children at Oregon farm|last=Stolberg|first=Sheryl|date=1991-09-06|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.apnews.com/bc9be8e44a2fdcf11ea69b1659c0cf83|title=Founder of Ecclesia Assn, Where Girl Beaten To Death in 1988, Dies At 39|last=McCall|first=William|date=2018-09-05|work=AP News|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en-US}}</ref> Broussard had been a basketball star at [[Pacific University]], was drafted by the [[Portland Trail Blazers]], and was ordained a minister.<ref name=":5" /> He founded the Ecclesia Athletic Association with the goal to "lift children out of the dead-end ghetto life through athletic training and strict discipline".<ref name=":0" /> With the help of donations which for some members amounted to their entire salaries, the church was able to buy an Avalon Boulevard bakery to serve as a commune.<ref name="LAT" />
In 1977 Broussard shifted his focus from the Watts Christian Center, which had lost most of its membership, to the Ecclesia Athletic Association, founded by Broussard and the few remaining members of the Christian Center.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-11-01/news/mn-636_1_miracle-child|title=Miracle Child Was Messiah to Followers in Watts Group|last=Murphy|first=Kim|date=1988-11-01|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> Ecclesia sponsored a successful 32-team basketball league, the largest in Los Angeles at the time, and Broussard's sister ran a school focusing on nutrition;<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/clackamascounty/index.ssf/1988/10/ecclesia_death_and_contradicti.html|title=Ecclesia: Death and contradictions in Oregon compound|last=Ellis|first=Barnes|date=1988-10-23|work=OregonLive.com|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en-US}}</ref> children in the care of the Ecclesia Athletic Association stopped receiving formal schooling in 1984.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-11-15/local/me-255_1_reform-schools|title=Children of Ecclesia Slow to Cut Ties to Past|last=Stolberg|first=Sheryl|date=1988-11-15|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> By this time, accusations that the group was a cult were being made publicly. Broussard, who was called "The Coach" or "El" by members,<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-06-22/news/mn-5174_1_quiet-life|title=Ecclesia--New Life or Another Cult Invasion?|last=Timnick|first=Lois|date=1987-06-22|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref><ref name=":6" /> denied Ecclesia was a cult, saying: "People who call us a cult group have never been [to the Avalon Boulevard building]. They have never examined us. They assume people are kept here because they see our discipline, because our kids walk in a straight line".<ref name=":1" /> The children were described as "hav[ing] a very clear picture in their minds that they don't want to be the same as other blacks in the Watts community".<ref name=":4" /> David Jackson, who was 14 when he and his mother Constance Jackson joined the EAA, credits Broussard with rescuing him from gangs, ""[Broussard] actually was the person that got me out of gangs in LA and...taught me that I have options..."<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/blazers/index.ssf/2014/10/trail_blazers_dj_og_one_endures_long_climb_to_the.html|title=Trail Blazers' DJ O.G. One endures long climb to the top of section 225|last=Richman|first=Mike|date=2018-11-06|work=OregonLive.com|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Move to Oregon == The bulk of the group's members moved to [[Sandy, Oregon]], in 1987,<ref name="WaPo">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1988/10/25/ecclesia-group-was-a-mystery-to-community_until-girl-died/b337131c-6fec-44e4-a1c8-479dfcff12a2/|title=Ecclesia Group was a Mystery to Community until Girl Died|last=Parker|first=Laura|date=1988-10-25|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> though they did maintain their Avalon Boulevard headquarters.<ref name="LAT" /> The Sandy property offered a lot more space–{{convert|18.5|acre}}–on which Broussard told neighbors they planned to build pools and gymnasiums.<ref name="WaPo" /> Broussard told the neighbors of their "plan for the welfare of a lost generation".<ref name="WaPo" /> Ecclesia bragged of the extensive calisthenics, including one to five thousand continuous [[jumping jack]]s that the children in its care could do as part of the goal of training them to be Olympic athletes.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="WaPo" />
By late 1988 Ecclesia housed 53 children ranging in age from six weeks to sixteen years,<ref name="WaPo" /> and the group had a second house in [[Clackamas County, Oregon|Clackamas]].<ref name=":1" /> The parents of these children were all members of the group; they had been forced to sign a vow of poverty upon joining the group which put themselves, their children, and their assets under Broussard's control.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="WaPo" /> The life of residents in Oregon was highly regimented, with the children training under the supervision of Broussard's oldest son, Eldridge Broussard III, who had been born in 1976.<ref name=":5" /> During a reporter's visit to Oregon, teens and adults were observed working long days in the fields, unable to talk or sing because it would, according to a group spokeswoman, lower productivity.<ref name=":5" /> Jackson, who was 18 and a trainer when the EAA moved to Oregon, described the conditions as basic.<ref name=":8" />
Neighbors did not notice any signs of bruising or other scars when they saw the children, and lent advice and equipment to Ecclesia for their farming activities.<ref name="WaPo" /><ref name=":1" /> Some neighbors did experience unusual interactions with the children, not seeing them play, and once one of the children explained she was unable to speak to a neighbor who should instead talk to Ecclesia's minister of external affairs. Some neighbors feared the group was a cult reminiscent of the followers of [[Rajneesh]].<ref name="WaPo" /> Their suspicions grew when Ecclesia began planting more crops, claimed to have grown {{convert|91000|lb}} of produce, and attempted to secure permission to place more tents and outdoor toilets across its property in order to legally house 100 people.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="WaPo" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-06-29/news/mn-233_1_vow|title=Ecclesia to Drop Housing Proposal|last=From United Press International|first=|date=1987-06-29|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
Neighbors who suspected that the children were being abused repeatedly called authorities.<ref name=":1" /> A deputy who was dispatched after several complaints found 50 children living in a sweltering garage but took no action, with the Oregon Children's Services Division also declining to investigate, as association members explained the children were in a training session.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="WaPo" /> Following an outcry at the zoning application by its neighbors, which included the public release of the vow of poverty, Ecclesia withdrew its application and seemingly abandoned the property in October 1987.<ref name="WaPo" /><ref name=":5" /> The group had also faced resistance from neighbors in Clackamas, where Broussard was informed his land was zoned for farming, not for housing large numbers of children.<ref name=":1" />
== Death of Dayna Broussard == On October 14, 1988, four members of Ecclesia, Willie K. Chambers, Brian James Brinson, Constance Zipporah Jackson, and Frederick Paul Doolittle, brought the body of Dayna Broussard, Eldrige's 8-year-old daughter and the second oldest of five children, to the Sandy fire station.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name="WaPo" /> The four were arrested and charged with [[Manslaughter (United States law)|manslaughter]].<ref name="WaPo" /> Eldridge had been in Los Angeles at the time of his daughter's death,<ref name=":0" /> but members of Ecclesia had begun returning to Sandy two months earlier.<ref name=":1" /> While investigating the death of Dayna, child welfare officials learned that 42 of the 53 children, all those who were older than five, were subjected to beatings of at least 100 lashes with paddles and an electrical cord and had been scarred.<ref name="WaPo" /><ref name=":1" /> The children were also regularly forced to watch others being punished; many had watched the punishment of Dayna which led to her death.<ref name="WaPo" /> In an [[affidavit]], officials described a "cruel and terrifying experience, giving rise to mental injury".<ref name="WaPo" /> The children were also regularly forced to go with limited food, sleep on the floor, and share only one or two working bathrooms.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="WaPo" /> Authorities explained that no children had attempted to run away because Ecclesia was the only life they knew.<ref name=":1" />
Broussard said that the conditions authorities found were due to inexperienced members being placed in charge of the children while he was away. He defended the punishments while talking about the beatings he had experienced from his father and the cultural differences between Watts and Oregon.<ref name="WaPo" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1988/10/20/A-Los-Angeles-ghetto-pastor-said-Thursday-allegations-of/3854593323200/|title=A Los Angeles ghetto pastor said Thursday allegations of...|last=Lesar|first=Jack|date=1988-10-20|work=UPI|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en}}</ref> Following his daughter's death, Broussard announced he was going to shut down both the Ecclesia Athletic Association and the Watts Christian Center.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-07-25/news/mn-1036_1_broussard|title=Ecclesia Leader Tells Mourners He'll Suspend Group's Activities|last=Press|first=From Associated|date=1987-07-25|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> However, Ecclesia continued to operate.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-07-08/local/me-2678_1_children-returned-plan|title=Plan for Return of Children Rejected|date=1989-07-08|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> In the aftermath, Broussard's brother Alvin was arrested for beating a 10-year-old boy at their Watts headquarters but prosecutors declined to charge Alvin with a felony.<ref name=":2" /> The Oregon Children's Services Division defended their failure to investigate, stating: "The issues raised were not neglect or child abuse, which is the only reasons we can go out in an investigation. They felt that the kids weren't being parented properly and that's not something we go out on. If we went out on every case of parenting skills, first of all we couldn't do it, and second, people would be angry at us".<ref name=":1" />
== Removal of children to state care == Once in state care, most of the children were placed in two [[reform schools]], with the remainder being placed in [[foster care]].<ref name=":4" /> During this time, the children expressed more of a desire to see Broussard than their own parents.<ref name=":4" /> The children acted much younger than their age and had little in the way of traditional schooling, instead having biblical and fitness knowledge.<ref name=":4" /> The children were "abnormally quiet and compliant" when initially entering care, but became more rowdy when they discovered they would not be beaten for misbehaving.<ref name=":4" /> The state attempted to recoup over $30,000 (${{Inflation|index=US|value=30,000|start_year=1988|fmt=c}} in present US dollars) in costs of caring for the children removed from their parents,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-11-13/local/me-4426_1_oregon-attorney|title=Oregon Has Difficulty Obtaining Child Care Debt|date=1990-11-13|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> though the overall costs of the care were substantially more.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-01-12/local/me-314_1_ecclesia-founder|title=Local News in Brief : Funds for Care of Ecclesia Youths OKd|date=1989-01-12|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
By the end of 1988, Oregon state officials wanted to return some children to California to live with relatives.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-12-03/local/me-919_1_oregon-authorities|title=Oregon Prepares to Return Some Ecclesia Children to California|last=Stolberg|first=Sheryl|date=1988-12-03|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> These plans were complicated a few weeks later when the children's parents, who had been visiting their children, announced that they would stop visiting as they refused to renounce their connection to Ecclesia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-01-25/news/mn-1040_1_parents-letter|title=Ecclesia Parents Cut Off Visits to Their Children|last=Services|first=From Times Wire|date=1989-01-25|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> Ecclesia faced its own roadblocks in reunification when a judge blocked its request in July 1989 to let the children participate in a summer camp.<ref name=":7" /> Officials also tried, unsuccessfully, to prevent the children from meeting with defense lawyers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-12-08/local/me-1162_1_ecclesia-children|title=Local News in Brief: Ecclesia Children to Be Questioned|date=1988-12-08|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
==Legal proceedings== The trial of Chambers, Brinson, Jackson, and Doolittle lasted three weeks. Many were angry that the defendants were only charged with manslaughter in Dayna's death, which the prosecutor explained by stating that more serious charges would have required more evidence of intent.<ref name="WaPo" /> During the trial, prosecutors said that Dayna's punishment stemmed from her stealing zucchini from another child and escalated from there.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1989/05/12/Four-Ecclesia-defendants-convicted-of-manslaughter/6721610948800/|title=Four Ecclesia defendants convicted of manslaughter|last=Mosier|first=Laura|date=1989-05-12|work=UPI|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en}}</ref> Several of the Ecclesia children testified that Dayna had been beaten 200 to 845 times, while children and adults testifying for the defense said it was 50 to 100 times.<ref name=":3" /> After a day of deliberation, the jury found all four defendants guilty of first-degree manslaughter.<ref name=":3" /> At the sentencing, Broussard asked the judge for [[clemency]], but the four were sentenced to the maximum 20 years. Brinson and Doolittle were eligible for parole in 40 months, Chambers and Jackson were eligible for parole in 10 years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1989/06/23/Ecclesia-members-get-20-years-in-beating-death/8133614577600/|title=Ecclesia members get 20 years in beating death|last=Dipietro|first=Benji|date=|work=UPI|access-date=2018-09-30|language=en}}</ref>
On February 7, 1991, Federal prosecutors indicted Broussard, his brother, Chambers, Jackson, and four others for [[child slavery]] under the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|13th Amendment]], and denying children their civil rights.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/us/commune-chief-charged-with-child-slavery.html|title=Commune Chief Charged With Child Slavery|last=AP|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.questia.com/read/117457302/cults-in-our-midst|title=Cults in Our Midst|last=Singer|first=Margaret Thaler|date=2003|publisher=Jossey-Bass|year=|isbn=0-7879-6741-6|edition= Rev.|location=San Francisco, CA|pages=85|oclc=50803257|subscription=yes|via=Questia}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/fl-xpm-1991-02-09-9101070722-story.html|title=L.S. Cult Leader, 7 Others Charged with Child Slavery|last=Times|first=Los Angeles|work=Sun-Sentinel.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Stephen Peifer, an [[Assistant United States Attorney|Assistant U.S. Attorney]] who was involved in prosecuting the case, called Ecclesia "the largest child slavery ring in the history of the United States".<ref name="LAT" /> While still awaiting trial, Broussard, who had become more reclusive following the indictments and convictions, died of complications from [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] on September 5, 1991.<ref name="LAT" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/13/us/autopsy-on-group-s-founder.html|title=Autopsy on Group's Founder|last=|first=|date=1991-09-13|work=New York Times|access-date=}}</ref> On January 17, 1992, the remaining seven "pleaded guilty ... to lesser charges and were given prison terms ranging from 2 1/4 to 8 years".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-01-19/local/me-955_1_lesser-charges|title=7 Plead Guilty to Conspiracy in Ecclesia Child Beatings|last=Associated Press|first=|date=1992-01-19|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
Brinson was released early from his 20-year prison sentence. In 2002 he was charged with several counts of sexual abuse and found guilty of one count. The charges were unrelated to his involvement in Ecclesia. In May 2013, he was shot to death by two teenagers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://katu.com/archive/man-convicted-in-1988-ecclesia-death-shot-to-death|title=Man convicted in 1988 'Ecclesia' death shot to death|work=KATU|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Child abuse in the United States]] [[Category:Clackamas County, Oregon]] [[Category:Contemporary slavery in the United States]]
