{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada |type = Department |nativename = {{lang|fr|Affaires autochtones et du Nord Canada}} |logo = |agency_type = [[Ministry (government department)|Department]] responsible for {{unbulleted list|First Nations|Nunavut|Northwest Territories|Yukon (external issues only)}} |jurisdiction = [[Government of Canada|Canada]] |employees = 4500+ |headquarters = [[Gatineau]], [[Quebec]], Canada |budget = [[Canadian dollar|CAD$]]8.1 billion (2015)<ref>{{cite web | title = Public Accounts of Canada 2015 Volume II Section 15 - Indian Affairs and Northern Development Ministry summary | publisher = [[Government of Canada]] | year = 2015 | url = http://www.tpsgc-pwgsc.gc.ca/recgen/cpc-pac/2015/vol2/aadnc-aandc/spm-ms-eng.html | accessdate = 19 Feb 2017}} </ref> |minister1_name = [[Carolyn Bennett]] |minister1_pfo = [[Minister of Crown–Indigenous Relations]] |minister2_name = [[Jane Philpott]] |minister2_pfo = [[Minister of Indigenous Services]] |deputyminister1_name = Colleen Swords |formed = 1966 |dissolved = |website = {{url|http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/}} }} [[File:Terrasses de la Chaudière.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Terrasses de la Chaudière]] houses the departmental headquarters in [[Gatineau]], [[Quebec]].]]
The '''Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development''' ('''DIAND'''), referred to by its applied title under the ''[[Federal Identity Program]]'' as '''Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada''' ('''INAC'''), ({{lang-fr|Affaires autochtones et du Nord Canada}}, AANC), is the [[Ministry (government department)|department]] of the [[government of Canada]] with responsibility for policies relating to [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada]], that comprise the [[First Nations]],{{sfn|CMC|2006}}<ref name="First Nations Culture Areas Index">{{cite web | title = Civilization.ca-Gateway to Aboriginal Heritage-Culture | work = Canadian Museum of Civilization Corporation | publisher = Government of Canada | date = May 12, 2006 | url = http://www.civilization.ca/cmc/exhibitions/tresors/ethno/etb0170e.shtml | accessdate =2009-09-18 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091020033621/http://www.civilization.ca/cmc/exhibitions/tresors/ethno/etb0170e.shtml| archivedate= 20 October 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Inuit]],<ref name="ICCcharter">{{cite web |title=Inuit Circumpolar Council (Canada)-ICC Charter |work=Inuit Circumpolar Council > ICC Charter and By-laws > ICC Charter |publisher= |year=2007 |url=http://inuitcircumpolar.com/index.php?auto_slide=&ID=374&Lang=En&Parent_ID=&current_slide_num= |accessdate=2009-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100305060320/http://inuitcircumpolar.com/index.php?auto_slide=&ID=374&Lang=En&Parent_ID=&current_slide_num= |archivedate=2010-03-05 |df= }} </ref> and [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]].<ref>{{cite web |title=In the Kawaskimhon Aboriginal Moot Court Factum of the Federal Crown Canada |work=Faculty of Law |publisher=[[University of Manitoba]] |year=2007 |url=http://www.umanitoba.ca/law/newsite/kawaskimhon_factums/FINALWrittenSubmissionsofFederalCrown_windsor.pdf |format=pdf |page=2 |accessdate=2009-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5lOHtrRJy?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.umanitoba.ca%2Flaw%2Fnewsite%2Fkawaskimhon_factums%2FFINALWrittenSubmissionsofFederalCrown_windsor.pdf |archivedate=2009-11-19 |df= }} </ref>
The department is overseen by two cabinet ministers, the [[Minister of Crown–Indigenous Relations]] (whose portfolio includes treaty rights and land negotiations) and the [[Minister of Indigenous Services]] (whose portfolio includes health care, water, and other services to Indigenous communities).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fife|first1=Robert|title=Indigenous Affairs department to be restructured in cabinet shuffle|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/indigenous-affairs-department-to-be-restructured-in-cabinet-shuffle-source/article36099306/|accessdate=August 28, 2017|work=The Globe & Mail|date=August 28, 2017}}</ref> Its headquarters are in [[Terrasses de la Chaudière]], in downtown [[Gatineau]], [[Quebec]].<ref>"[http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1291132820288/1291132853616 Contact Us]." Indian and Northern Affairs Canada. Retrieved on February 4, 2011. "Indian and Northern Affairs Canada Terrasses de la Chaudière 10 Wellington, North Tower Gatineau, Quebec." and "Indian and Northern Affairs Canada Room 2107 10 Wellington Street Gatineau, QC." [http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/fra/1291132820288/1291132853616 Address in French]: "Affaires indiennes et du Nord Canada Terrasses de la Chaudière 10, rue Wellington, Tour Nord Gatineau (Québec)." and "Affaires indiennes et du Nord Canada Pièce 2107 10, rue Wellington Gatineau, (QC)."</ref>
== Nomenclature == Pursuant to the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development Act<ref>Government of Canada. [http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/I-6/page-1.html#h-1 Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development Act (R.S.C., 1985, c. I-6)]. Justice Canada: Laws. Retrieved on: 2013-10-30.</ref> the term "Indian" remains in the department's legal name, although the term "Indigenous" is used in its applied title under the [[Federal Identity Program]].<ref>Treasury Board of Canada. [http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/fip-pcim/reg-eng.asp Registry of Applied Titles]. Federal Identity Program. Retrieved on: 2013-01-30.</ref><ref>Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada. [http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1100100010002/1100100010021]. AANDC website. Retrieved on: 2013-01-30.</ref>
First Nation,{{sfn|AADNC|2012}} has been used since the 1970s instead of the word "Indian", which some people found offensive.<ref name="TerminologyAINC" /> The term "Indian" is used for legal and historical documents such as [[Indian Register|Status Indian]]s as defined by the ''[[Indian Act]]''. For example, the term "Indian" continues to be used in the historical and legal document, the [[Constitution of Canada|Canadian Constitution]] and federal statutes. Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada used the term Inuit in referring to "an Aboriginal people in Northern Canada, who live in Nunavut, Northwest Territories, Northern Quebec and Northern Labrador. The word means "people" in the Inuit language — Inuktitut. The singular of Inuit is Inuk." <ref name="TerminologyAINC" /> Eskimo is found in historical documents about Canadian Inuit. The term "Aboriginal" is commonly used when referring to the three groups of indigenous peoples as a whole.<ref name="TerminologyAINC">{{cite web|url=http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ap/tln-eng.asp|title=Terminology|work=Indian and Northern Affairs Canada| accessdate =2009-10-05 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091027041022/http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ap/tln-eng.asp| archivedate= 27 October 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> It is also used by Aboriginal people who live within Canada who claim rights of sovereignty or Aboriginal title to lands.
==Departmental mandate== Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada (INAC) is one of the federal government departments responsible for meeting the Government of Canada's obligations and commitments to First Nations, Inuit and Métis, and for fulfilling the federal government's constitutional responsibilities in the North. INAC's responsibilities are largely determined by numerous statutes, negotiated agreements and relevant legal decisions. Most of the Department's programs, representing a majority of its spending - are delivered through partnerships with Aboriginal communities and federal-provincial or federal-territorial agreements. INAC also works with urban Indigenous people, Métis and Non-Status Indians (many of whom live in rural areas).<ref name="aadnc-aandc.gc.ca">http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1100100010023/1100100010027</ref>
Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada (INAC) supports indigenous peoples (First Nations, Inuit and Métis) and Northerners in their efforts to: * improve social well-being and economic prosperity; * develop healthier, more sustainable communities; and * participate more fully in Canada's political, social and economic development to the benefit of all Canadians.<ref name="aadnc-aandc.gc.ca"/>
INAC also works with urban First Nations, Métis and [[Non-Status Indian]]s (many of whom live in rural areas) through the [[Federal Interlocutor for Métis and Non-Status Indians|Office of the Federal Interlocutor]].<ref name="About INAC">[http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1100100010023/1100100010027 ''About INAC'']</ref> INAC also manages the resources and lands of federal lands, including land and subsurface leases and resource royalties.
==History== {{Indigenous Peoples of Canada}}
===Aboriginal Affairs=== {{Main article|The Canadian Crown and Aboriginal peoples}} In 1755, the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|British Crown]] established the [[Indian Department|British Indian Department]]. The Indian Governors General held control of Indian Affairs, but usually delegated much of their responsibility to a series of Civil Secretaries. In 1860, the responsibility for Indian affairs was transferred from the government of [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Great Britain]] to the [[Province of Canada]] and the responsibility for Indian Affairs was given to the Crown Lands Department Commissions Responsible for Indian Affairs.
The federal government's legislative responsibilities for Indians and Inuit derive from section 91(24) of the [[Constitution Act, 1867]] and responsibility was given to the Secretary of State for the Provinces Responsible for Indian Affairs. In 1876, the Indian Act, which remains the major expression of federal jurisdiction in this area, was passed and a series of [[Treaty#Treaties and indigenous peoples|treaties]]<ref>[http://epe.lac-bac.gc.ca/100/205/301/ic/cdc/treaties/code/default.htm ''Selected Treaties from the National Archives of Canada'']</ref> were concluded between Canada and the various [[First Nations government (Canada)|Indian bands]] across the country.
The responsibility for Indian Affairs and Northern Development rested with various government departments between 1873 and 1966. The [[Minister of the Interior (Canada)|Minister of the Interior]] also held the position of Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs after the Indian Affairs Department was established in 1880. In 1939, federal jurisdiction for Indian peoples was interpreted by the courts to apply to the Inuit. A revised Indian Act was passed in 1951.
From 1950 to 1965, the Indian Affairs portfolio was carried by the [[Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (Canada)|Minister of Citizenship and Immigration]]. On October 1, 1966, the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development was created as a result of the Government Organization Act, 1966.<ref>[http://www.lac-bac.gc.ca/databases/indianaffairs/001074-200-e.html ''Departments that have been responsible for Indian Affairs''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706182158/http://www.lac-bac.gc.ca/databases/indianaffairs/001074-200-e.html |date=2011-07-06 }}</ref> Effective June 13, 2011, the department began using the applied title Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada in addition to the legal name of the department.<ref name=change/>
====Northern Development==== The Northern Development part of the department has its origins in the [[Department of the Interior (Canada)|Department of the Interior]], a body created by then [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[John A. Macdonald]] for the purpose of administering the [[Dominion Lands Act]] of 1872. When the Department of the Interior dissolved in 1936 (with the [[Natural Resources Acts]] transferring control over natural resources to the [[Canadian Prairies|Prairie provinces]]), Indian Affairs fell under the purview of the [[Natural Resources Canada|Department of Mines and Resources]]. However, the need for social and health-care services in the North led to the establishment of the Northern Administration and Lands branch in 1951, which led to the creation of the Department of Northern Affairs and National Resources in 1953. This became the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development in 1966.<ref name=change>[http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ai/aand-eng.asp "Change to the Department's Name"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807075513/http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ai/aand-eng.asp |date=2011-08-07 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.lac-bac.gc.ca/databases/indianaffairs/001074-200-e.html ''departments that have been responsible for Northern Affairs''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706182158/http://www.lac-bac.gc.ca/databases/indianaffairs/001074-200-e.html |date=2011-07-06 }}</ref> Under the [[Federal Identity Program]], the department is known as Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada.
====Annual Arctic expeditions==== Beginning in the early 20th century, the Canadian government sponsored annual expeditions to the [[northern Canada|Canadian North]]. These expeditions yielded extensive photographic documentation of the lives of northern indigenous peoples by participating explorers, engineers, scientists and medical staff.
Explorer, photographer, filmmaker, writer and lecturer Richard S. Finnie accompanied numerous expeditions to the North. His first voyage was aboard [[CGS Arctic|CGS ''Arctic'']], under the command of [[Joseph-Elzéar Bernier|Captain Bernier]] in 1924. During the 1930–1931 expedition to the Western Arctic, Finnie served as filmmaker. Lachlan T. Burwash, an exploratory engineer with the Department of the Interior, made a survey of the east coasts of [[Hudson Bay]] and [[James Bay]], and the [[Belcher Islands]] in the late 1920s.
[[Zoologist]] Joseph Dewey Soper travelled to the [[Baffin Island]] (Qikiqtaaluk) region in the late 1920s in order to document the landscape, as well as the plant and bird life. [[J.G. Wright]], Superintendent of Eastern Arctic Patrol and [[National Film Board of Canada|National Film Board]] photographer, served on the 1945–1946 expedition sponsored by the [[CNIB|Canadian National Institute for the Blind]]. As the Regional Director of [[Child benefit|Family Allowances]] for [[Yukon]] and the [[Northwest Territories]], S.J. Bailey served as part of the Eastern Arctic Patrol beginning in the late 1940s.
==Organization== Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada has offices in ten (10) regions, at headquarters and to deal with oil and gas leases. The offices are further divided into the broad divisions of treaties and aboriginal government; lands and economic development and education and social development. Northern Development is represented in only the Northwest Territories (NWT) and Nunavut (NU) regional offices and headquarters.
=="The Nunavut Project"== The [[Nunavut Land Claims Agreement]] was implemented in 1993 between the Inuit of the Nunavut Settlement Area and the Government of Canada subject to the [[Constitution Act, 1982|Constitution Act of 1982]]. The territory of Nunavut was formed in 1999. INAC has major responsibilities for managing the lands and resources of Nunavut.
With respect to the Inuit of [[Nunavut]], the department and its Minister have the challenge of implementing the Conciliator’s Final Report, dated March 1, 2006 on the Nunavut Land Claims Agreement Implementation Contract Negotiations for the Second Planning Period 2003-2013 "The Nunavut Project" authored by [[Thomas R. Berger|Thomas Berger]].<ref>[http://www.cba.org/nunavut/pdf/NU_finalreport.pdf ''The Nunavut Project''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205163724/http://www.cba.org/nunavut/pdf/NU_finalreport.pdf |date=2008-12-05 }}</ref> This report recommends an increase in Inuit participation in Nunavut's federal and territorial public service.
==Community infrastructure==
By January 2012 there were two government audits that revealed that the federal government had earmarked about a billion dollars annually on constructing and/or maintaining First Nations infrastructure in First Nations communities.<ref name=scoffield2012>{{cite web |title=Oversight lacking for $1B in First Nations infrastructure funds: audit |url=http://www.ipolitics.ca/2012/01/05/oversight-lacking-for-1b-in-first-nations-infrastructure-funds-audits/ |author=Heather Scoffield |date=January 5, 2012 }}</ref>
"Findings from the "AFN First Nations Regional Longitudinal Health Survey 2002/2003 study (March 2007) are notable: More than 1/5 of adult respondents report that they have no access to garbage collection services; Nine percent of homes do not have either sewage service or a septic tank; and Only 2/3 of respondents considered their water safe to drink: Over 60 percent of respondents obtain their drinking water from bottled water. To cite a 2003 INAC study, 39 percent of water systems exceeded one or more of the risk indicator thresholds occasionally or continuously. Among key informants, there was unanimous consensus that there is a clear infrastructure deficit on reserve and in the different categories, according to the community; investment needed in housing, school, water facilities, and roads were usually mentioned as examples."<ref name=evaluationFNIF2010>{{cite report |publisher=Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada |title=Implementation Evaluation of the First Nation Infrastructure Fund |date= February 2010 |url=http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1324657420031/1324657571041 }}</ref>
Community Infrastructure $1.028 billion
===First Nations Infrastructure Fund (FNIF)=== FNIF $234 million (lifespan)
The First Nations Infrastructure Fund (FNIF) was introduced in 2007 to improve the quality of life and the environment for First Nation communities. It is a targeted fund that accepted proposals for community projects under the following headings: 1) Planning and Skills Development, 2) Solid Waste Management, 3) Roads and Bridges 4) Energy Systems 5) Connectivity. The amount available to each community through the First Nations Infrastructure Fund (FNIF) was limited to a total of $10 million over a five-year period. By March 2008, a total of 262 proposals (out of the 714 submitted) were approved for FNIF funding. Nationally, $94.3 million of FNIF funding was dispersed.<ref name="scoffield2012"/> <ref name=evaluationFNIF2010 />
First Nations Water and Wastewater Action Plan (FNWWAP) $2.5 billion (lifespan)7 N/A
==Infrastructure crisis in First Nations communities==
===Crisis in water supply, distribution systems and wastewater systems===
In 2005, the Office of the Auditor General of Canada "reported the lack of a legislative regime to ensure that water quality on reserves met the Guidelines for Canadian Drinking Water Quality, despite the existence of such a regime in every province and territory (OAG 2011 page 11)."<ref name=reportOAG2011>{{cite report |title=2011 June Status Report of the Auditor General of Canada |url=http://www.oag-bvg.gc.ca/internet/docs/parl_oag_201106_04_e.pdf |format=PDF |chapter=Chapter 4: Programs for First Nations on Reserves |accessdate=January 12, 2013 |author=Office of the Auditor General of Canada }}</ref> The auditor general's report (2011-06) noted that INAC and Health Canada "do not ensure that drinking water is tested on a regular basis."<ref name=reportOAG2011 />
====National assessment of water and wastewater systems in First Nation communities====
In 1991, less than 80% of on-reserve housing had basic water and sewer services. (NAWWSFNS 2003:26)
By 2001, about 98% of on-reserve houses had water and 94% had sewer services. (NAWWSFNS 2003:26)
The report dated May 2003 revealed that "of the 740 community water systems assessed, about 29% posed a potentially high risk that could negatively impact water quality (p. i. ) Only 25% were in the low or no risk category. Of the 462 community waterwater systems assessed, 16% (74) were classified at a potential high risk that could negatively impact wastewater effluent quality. (p. ii.) Circuit Rider Training Program began in 2000. "The capital cost to address deficiencies to water and wastewater systems was estimated between $475 million and $560 million in 2003. The capital investment to provide basic water and wastewater services to about 5,300 homes which did not have basic water and wastewater services would have cost $185 million in 2003. Support for normal recapitalization and expansion for growth was estimated at $90 million to $100 million annually. p.iii)<ref name=water2003>{{cite report |url=http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/DAM/DAM-INTER-HQ/STAGING/texte-text/watw_1100100016374_eng.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Assessment of Water and Wastewater Systems in First Nation Communities |date=May 2003 |publisher=Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada |pages=27}}</ref>
"The National Assessment released in April 2011 was the result of "the most rigorous and comprehensive evaluation of water and wastewater systems on reserve ever under taken. Between July 2009 and spring 2011, independent engineers inspected 4000 on-reserve systems including 1,300 water and wastewater systems and more than 800 wells and 1,900 septic fields serving 571 First Nation communities."<ref name=AANDC2011>{{cite web |date=November 8, 2011 |title=Frequently Asked Questions - National Assessment of Water and Wastewater Systems in First Nation Communities: Release of Final Reports: National Assessment Results |url=http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1313691954022/1313692022231 |publisher=Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada |location=Gatineau, Quebec |accessdate=February 9, 2013 }}</ref>
The National Assessment of Water and Wastewater Systems in First Nation Communities (2011) "found that 39 per cent of First Nations water systems were at high risk of being unsafe, affecting 25 per cent of people living on reserves. It said Ottawa would need $1.2 billion in repairs, better infrastructure and training to fix the problem, as well as an additional $4.7 billion over 10 years to keep pace with growing demand."<ref name=scoffield2012 />
39% of the 807 water systems inspected were classified as high overall risk affecting 25 per cent of the on-reserve population base. The study found that "314 water systems were high risk, 161 water systems in 116 First Nation communities were under Health Canada Drinking-Water Advisories (DWA) as of February 2011. These DWAs may be impacting up to 18,900 people, which is approximately 3.9 percent of the total on-reserve population cited as 484,321 in the National Roll-up."<ref name=AANDC201107>{{cite web |date=July 2011 |title=Frequently Asked Questions - National Assessment of Water and Wastewater Systems in First Nation Communities: Fact Sheet |url=http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1313762701121/1313762778061 |publisher=Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada |location=Gatineau, Quebec |accessdate=February 9, 2013 }}</ref>
The National Assessment of Water and Wastewater Systems in First Nation Communities 'suggests many communities remain vulnerable to the health and environmental problems that result from poor water quality and inadequate sanitation. The assessment, which was released in April 2011, looked at the water and sewer systems of 571 First Nations (with a total population of 484,321 and 112,836 "dwellings") and evaluated their water source and how well each system was designed, operated and monitored. It categorized 39 per cent of the water systems as "high risk," meaning they have "major deficiencies" that pose a high risk to water quality and could lead to potential health and safety or environmental concerns. Thirty-four per cent were assessed as posing medium risk to the quality of water and health and having deficiencies that "should be corrected to avoid future problems." <ref name=huffintonpost20130209> {{cite web |title=Clean Running Water Still A Luxury On Many Native Reserves |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2011/11/30/clean-water-native-reserves-attawapiskat_n_1120102.html |date=February 9, 2013 |author=CBC |accessdate=February 9, 2013 }}</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT:Indian And Northern Affairs Canada}} [[Category:Indigenous peoples in Canada]] [[Category:Indigenous health in Canada]] [[Category:Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada| ]] [[Category:Indigenous affairs ministries|Canada]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1966]] [[Category:1966 establishments in Canada]] [[Category:Gatineau]]

{{Redirect|IDPN|the chemical|IDPN (chemical)}} '''Intradialytic parenteral nutrition''' ('''IDPN''') is a nutritional support therapy ([[medical nutrition therapy]]) for people on [[hemodialysis]] who have a difficult time maintaining adequate nutrition. It is administered directly into the bloodstream of patients suffering from [[chronic kidney disease]] (CKD) in an effort to decrease the associated morbidity and mortality experienced in patients with [[renal failure]]. IDPN contains protein ([[amino acid]]s), [[carbohydrate]]s ([[dextrose]]), and [[fat]]s ([[lipids]]) in an attempt to meet a patient's weekly nutritional needs. Solutions can be individualized for each patient based on weight, needs, medical history and enteral intake.
==History== Prior to 1990, traditional therapies for [[dialysis]] patients such as liberalized diet and oral supplements, led to protein malnutrition and/or calorie malnutrition.
Efforts to supplement nutritional intake by providing nutrients during the dialysis procedure were attempted. As a result, IDPN became an established therapy to replete malnourished CKD-5 dialysis patients in the early 1990s. Generally the patients received a set formulation containing standard amounts of dextrose, amino acids and lipids regardless of the patient's weight, dialysis time and complicating co-morbid conditions.
==New approach to IDPN therapy== To address specific nutritional needs of individual patients, several providers of IDPN therapy developed formulations that take clinical variables into account in order to best fit the patient’s individual needs and condition. Specific formulations address distinct differences between nutritional needs of those patients who exhibit protein malnutrition and those patients who exhibit calorie malnutrition.
==See also== *[[Nutrition]] *[[Clinical nutrition]]

revision.comment: Tassedethe moved page [[John Naysmyth (surgeon)]] to [[John Naysmyth]]: no need for dab
revision.text:
'''John Naysmith (or Naismyth or Nasmyth)''' (1556-16 September 1613) was a Scottish surgeon who became surgeon to King James VI of Scotland and was appointed Royal Herbalist in London when the monarch became King James VI and I. He was Deacon (President) of the Incorporation of Surgeons and Barbers of Edinburgh. == Early life and education == John Naysmith was the younger son of Sir Michael Naysmyth (or Nasmyth) of Posso (1516-1607), Chamberlain to [[John Hamilton (archbishop of St Andrews)|John Hamilton, the archbishop of St Andrews]].Comrie, J.D. ''History of Scottish Medicine to 1860''. London, Wellcome Historical Medical Museum, 2nd ed, 1932 p 174 https://archive.org/details/b2045711x His mother was Elizabeth,(1503-1606) daughter of John Baird of Posso (1483-1526), owner of the estate of that name in Peebles-shire.Michael Naesmyth https://www.ancestry.co.uk/genealogy/records/michael-naesmyth_19269434 His elder brother James Naysmith inherited the Posso estate and became falconer to King James VI. John Naysmyth's early education was at [[St Mary's College, St Andrews]] after which he was apprenticed to the surgeon [[Gilbert Primrose (surgeon)|Gilbert Primrose]] in Edinburgh.Anderson, William. ''The Scottish nation; or. The surnames, families, literature, honours, and biographical history of the people of Scotland''. Edinburgh, Fullarton and Co, 1867 https://archive.org/details/scottishnationo05andegoog He was admitted to the Incorporation of Surgeons and Barbers of Edinburgh in 1588.Gairdner, John. ''Historical sketch of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh''. Edinburgh, Sutherland and Knox, 1860. https://archive.org/details/b2145209x He married Helen Macmath in Edinburgh on 26 March 1600.OPR register indexes NASMYTH, JOHNNE; HELENE MCMATHE/FR652 (FR652); 131; 26/03/1600; 685/1; 430 30; Edinburgh from https://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk == Career == He was elected [[List of Presidents of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh|Deacon (President)]] of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh|Incorporation of Surgeons and Barbers of Edinburgh]] in 1595. Gilbert Primrose, his surgical master had been surgeon to [[King James VI]] and became [[Serjeant-Surgeon]] to King James VI and I when the King and his court moved to London. Presumably as a result of Primrose’s patronage Naysmith was made a surgeon to King James VI, and he too moved with the Court to London on the occasion of the Union of the Crowns. King James VI, now King James I made him Royal Herbalist for life. During his time in London he attended Prince Henry during his fatal illness.Dingwall, Helen. ''A famous and flourishing Society ; The History of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh, 1505-2005''. Edinburgh, Edinburgh University press, 2005. p15 {{ISBN|978-0748615674}} == Political activity == Like his father he was an active supporter of [[Mary, Queen of Scots]]. It is thought that he was a member of Lord Seton's party, a small select group who were entrusted to journey to England in 1675, ostensibly to pay homage to Queen Elizabeth, but in reality to smuggle letters to the imprisoned [[Mary, Queen of Scots|Mary Queen of Scots]] from the then Scottish Regent, [[James Douglas, 4th Earl of Morton]]. This was achieved successfully, and, as a result of his part in this exploit he found favour with the teenage King James VI. Yet in an era of plotting and conspiracy and vaccillating political loyalty he had been suspected of involvement in the 1591 plot against the King by [[Francis Stewart, 5th Earl of Bothwell|Francis Stewart 5th Earl of Bothwell]]. He was imprisoned in Edinburgh Castle then Dumbarton Castle before being ordered by the privy council to go abroad under caution of 1000 merks (£666 Scots). The caution was subsequently deleted by warrant of the King on 1 August 1593.Dingwall, HM. ‘Nasmyth , John (1556/7–1613)’, ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/19796, accessed 10 May 2017] He fled to France where he became Chief Surgeon to the Scots Guards of the King of France.Forbes-Leith, William. ''The Scots Men at Arms in France.'' Vol 2; Edinburgh,W. Patterson, 1882.p187 Returning to Scotland in 1599, he appears to have been forgiven for his earlier infidelity, and was accepted back into the Royal Court. He was among the retainers with the King at Falkland Palace on the occasion of the [[Gowrie Conspiracy]] in 1600. Gilbert Primrose, his surgical master, had by now been made Serjeant-Surgeon (or Chief Surgeon) to King James VI. Naysmith became a surgeon to King James VI and, on the [[Union of the Crowns]] in 1603, he travelled with the Court to London. King James, now King James I of England, made him Royal Herbalist for life. == Death and burial == Naysmith died in London and was buried in Greyfriars churchyard in Edinburgh where an elaborate monument marks his grave.Brown, James ''Epitaphs in Greyfriars Churchyard''.Edinburgh, J. Moodie Miller, 1867. p10.https://play.google.com/books/reader?id=15EZAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&output=reader&hl=en_GB&pg=GBS.PP1 The inscription in Latin is now almost obliterated but has been translated as follows;
Here lies John Nasmyth, of the family of Posso, an honourable family of Tweedale, a citizen of Edinburgh, chief surgeon to his most Serene Majesty and to the King of France's troop of guards from Scotland - having excellently performedall the duties of a godly life; who dying at London to the grief of both nations, in the exercise of office with his Majesty, ordered his body to be conveyed hither (such was his love to his country), to be buried in this dormitory; acquiting himself to his King, his country and his friends by the utmost of his power and duty. He died in the 57th year of his age, the 10th of September 1613. Why is it grievous to return whence you came?
His testament was proved in the Edinburgh Commissary Court on 19 January 1614Nasmythe, Johne; 19/1/1614; chirurgeon to our Sovereign Lord, burgess of Edinburgh; Testament Testamentar and Inventory; Edinburgh Commissary Court; CC8/8/48 from https://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Scottish surgeons]] [[Category:1613 deaths]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Presidents of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]] [[Category:16th-century Scottish people]] [[Category:17th-century Scottish people]] [[Category:People of the Stuart period]] [[Category:1556 births]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Leïla Mezian Benjelloun | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Valencia]], Spain | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = Moroccan | education = | alma_mater = University of Madrid | occupation = | known for = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Othman Benjelloun]]|1960}} | children = 2 | parents = [[Mohamed Meziane]] | relatives = | website = }}
'''Leïla Mezian Benjelloun''' is a Moroccan physician and businesswoman, and the wife of billionaire [[Othman Benjelloun]].
==Early life== She is the daughter of Moroccan general [[Mohamed Meziane]].<ref name="100femmes.ma">{{cite web|url=http://www.100femmes.ma/en/femme/dr.leila.mezian.benjelloun|title=100 FEMMES - Dr Leïla MEZIAN-BENJELLOUN|author=|date=|website=www.100femmes.ma|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref> She was born in [[Valencia]], and grew up in Spain.<ref name="100femmes.ma"/> She is a graduate of the University of Madrid's medical school.<ref name="wise-qatar.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.wise-qatar.org/le%C3%AFla-mezian-benjelloun|title=Dr. Leïla Mezian Benjelloun|author=|date=|website=wise-qatar.org|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
==Career== She is president of the [[BMCE Bank Foundation]].<ref name="moroccanladies.com">{{cite web|url=http://moroccanladies.com/breaking-news/dr-leila-mezian-laid-the-foundation-stone-of-her-upcoming-museum-of-arts-and-traditions-18911|title=Dr. Leila Mezian laid the foundation stone of her upcoming Museum of Arts and Traditions - Moroccan Ladies|author=|date=30 October 2017|website=moroccanladies.com|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
In October 2017, she laid the foundation stone of the new 1200 m² [[Museum of Arts and Traditions of Morocco]] (MATM) that she is building at the junction of Moulay Youssef Boulevard and Roudani Boulevard in [[Casablanca]].<ref name="moroccanladies.com"/> The building will be 26 meters high and is budgeted to cost MAD 79 million.<ref name="moroccoworldnews.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2016/12/203947/leila-mezian-benjelloun-build-new-museum-casablanca/|title=Leila Mezian Benjelloun To Build a New Museum in Casablanca|author=|date=18 December 2016|website=moroccoworldnews.com|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref> The architect is [[Tarik Oualalou]].<ref name="moroccoworldnews.com"/> Completion is expected in 2018.<ref name="moroccanladies.com"/><ref name="moroccoworldnews.com"/>
She is president of the [[Alaouite Organization for the Protection of the Blind]] and the [[Moroccan Red Cross]], vice president of the [[Association of Medical Doctors in Morocco]], and president of the [[Benjelloun-Mezian Foundation]].<ref name="wise-qatar.org"/>
==Personal life== She is married to [[Othman Benjelloun]] since 1960, and they have two children, Dounia, a film producer, and Kamal, an anthropologist and environmentalist.<ref name="wise-qatar.org"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fm6e.org/mobile/en/weec-2013/2013-11-12-17-53-06/2013-11-12-18-32-10.html|title=Keynotes Speakers|first=|last=eCapital|date=|website=www.fm6e.org|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Benjelloun, Leïla Mezian}} {{Morocco-bio-stub}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Moroccan businesspeople]] [[Category:Moroccan women in business]] [[Category:Moroccan physicians]] [[Category:People from Valencia]]

{{Split|discuss=Talk:List of deaths in rock and roll#Split propsal|date=November 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{Very long|date=November 2017}} {{More citations needed|date=May 2016}} }} {{Dynamic list}} [[File:HollyMonument.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Monument at the crash site of the airplane carrying [[Buddy Holly]], [[The Big Bopper]], and [[Ritchie Valens]]; "[[The Day the Music Died]]".]] The following is a list of notable performers of [[rock and roll]] music or [[rock music]], and others directly associated with the music as producers, songwriters or in other closely related roles, who have died. The list gives their date, cause and location of death, and their age. Rock music developed from the rock and roll music that emerged during the 1950s, and includes a diverse range of subgenres. The terms "rock and roll" and "rock" each have a variety of definitions, some narrow and some wider. In determining criteria for inclusion, this list uses as its basis reliable sources listing "rock deaths" or "deaths in rock and roll", as well as such sources as the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]. ==1950s== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto;" |- ! style="background:#ace1af; color:black; width:150px;"| Name ! style="background:#ace1af; color:black; width:25px;"| Age ! style="background:#ace1af; color:black; width:125px;"| Date ! style="background:#ace1af; color:black; width:200px;"| Location ! style="background:#ace1af; color:black; width:300px;"| Cause of death |- | [[Kansas Joe McCoy]]

Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/81.97.245.234|81.97.245.234]] ([[User talk:81.97.245.234|talk]]): not providing a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] ([[WP:CITE]], [[WP:RS]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}}{{italic title}} {{Infobox Korean name | title = Mukbang | image = Muk-bang_video.jpg | caption = A thumbnail for a South Korean muk-bang YouTube video | hangul = {{lang|ko|[[wikt:먹다|먹]][[wikt:방송|방]]}} | rr = Meokbang | mr = Mŏkpang | koreanipa = {{IPA-ko|mʌk̚.p͈aŋ|}} | othername1 = Word origin | hangul1 = {{linktext|먹는| 방송}} | hanja1 = 먹는 {{linktext|放送}} | rr1 = Meongneun bangsong | mr1 = Mŏngnŭn pangsong | koreanipa1 = {{IPA-ko|mʌŋ.nɯn.baŋ.soŋ|}} | text = }} '''''Mukbang''''' or '''''muk-bang''''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|ʌ|k|b|æ|ŋ|,_|ˈ|m|ʊ|k|b|æ|ŋ}}; {{IPA-ko|mʌk̚.p͈aŋ|lang|Ko-먹방.ogg}}) is a live online audiovisual broadcast in which a host eats large amounts of foods while interacting with their audience. Usually done through an internet [[webcast]] (such streaming platforms include [[Afreeca]], [[YouTube|Youtube]], [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]] and etc), mukbang became popular in [[South Korea]] in the 2010s.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cha|first=Frances|date=2 February 2014|title=South Korea's online trend: Paying to watch a pretty girl eat|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/29/world/asia/korea-eating-room/|publisher=[[CNN]]|access-date=24 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Hu|first=Elise|date=24 March 2015|title=Koreans Have An Insatiable Appetite For Watching Strangers Binge Eat|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thesalt/2015/03/24/392430233/koreans-have-an-insatiable-appetite-for-watching-strangers-binge-eat|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=24 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=BBC>{{cite news |last=Evans|first=Stephen|date=5 February 2014|title=The Koreans who televise themselves eating dinner|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-31130947|publisher=[[BBC]]|access-date=24 March 2015}}</ref> Foods ranging from pizza to noodles are consumed in front of a camera for an internet audience (who pay or not, depending on which platform one is watching).
In each broadcast, a host will often interact with their viewers through [[online chat]]rooms. With the rising popularity of these eating shows, hosts have found lucrative ways of benefiting from the online show. Many hosts generate revenue through mukbang, by accepting donations or partnering with advertising networks.<ref name=BBC />
==Etymology== The word mukbang is a [[portmanteau]] of the Korean words for "eating" ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=[[wikt:먹다|먹는]]|rr=meokneun|labels=no}}) and "broadcast" ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=[[wikt:방송|방송]]|rr=bangsong|labels=no}}).<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ko:우리는 왜 '먹방'과의 사랑에 빠진 걸까?|trans-title=I Wonder Why we Fell in Love with "Muk-Bang"?|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20130426000792|accessdate=30 October 2015|work=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=26 April 2013|language=Korean}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Meok-Bang Trend In South Korea Turns Binge Eating Into Spectator Sport|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2013/12/18/meok-bang-trend_n_4467240.html|accessdate=30 October 2015|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=18 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-31130947|title=The Koreans who televise themselves eating dinner|last=Evans|first=Stephen|date=2015-02-05|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== History == The mukbang Internet culture began on [[AfreecaTV]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=우리나라 최초의 '먹방'을 아세요?|url=http://www.hankookilbo.com/v/46f6ed0fa3e14bd8920443a542920e4d|website=한국일보|accessdate=26 April 2017|language=ko}}</ref> The phenomenon of mukbang became more global interest after American entertainment duo "The Fine Brothers" created a video which shows the reaction of Western people to mukbang eating contests.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/05/04/mukbang-how-koreans-become-stars-through-their-love-of-food.html|title=Koreans become stars by live-streaming dinner|last=Gibbs|first=Alexandra|date=2015-05-05|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-10-29}}</ref>
== Reasons for popularity ==
There are several explanations given by various scholars. [[Jeff Yang]], an Asian-American cultural critic and senior vice president of the global research firm Kantar Futures, said that mukbang had its origins in "the loneliness of unmarried or uncoupled [South] Koreans, in addition to the inherently social aspect of eating in [South] Korea" during the interview with Quartz.<ref>Why some Koreans make $10,000 a month to eat on camera,http://qz.com/592710/why-some-koreans-make-10000-a-month-to-eat-on-camera/</ref>
Kim-Hae Jin, Ph.D candidate from [[Chosun University]], argued that one can vicariously satisfy the desire for the food. The hosts, who call themselves BJs (Broadcast Jockeys), interact with the people who are watching the broadcast through chatting. BJs sometimes claim to be the audience's "avatar" and will exactly follow what people ask them to do.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kim (김)|first=Hye Jin (혜진)|date=2015|title=문화학 : 하위문화로서의 푸드 포르노(Food Porn) 연구 - 아프리카TV의 인터넷 먹방을 중심으로 -|trans-title=A Study on Food Porn as a Sub-Culture - Centering on Internet "Meokbang" (eating scene) in Afreeca TV -|url=http://kiss.kstudy.com/thesis/thesis-view.asp?key=3370153|journal=인문학연구|language=ko-KR|volume=50|issue=0|pages=433–455|issn=1598-9259|via=RISS}}</ref>
Adema contends in her article: "food television incorporates the vicarious pleasures of watching someone else cook and eat; the emulsion of entertainment and cooking; the jumbling of traditional gender roles; and ambivalence toward cultural standards of body, consumption, and health. ... simultaneously perpetuates the stress of social expectations. "<ref>Adema, Pauline. "Vicarious consumption: Food, television and the ambiguity of modernity." The Journal of American Culture 23.3 (2000): 113. </ref>
==Varieties== Other genres of mukbang include "cook-bang" (cooking and eating) shows. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ikunkang.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=22294|title=TV를 삼킨 먹방 & 쿡방 열풍이 불편한 이유}}</ref>
South Korean video game players have sometimes broadcast mukbang as breaks during their overall streams. The popularity of this practice among local users led the video game streaming service [[Twitch.tv]] to begin trialling a dedicated "Social eating" category in July 2016; a representative of the service stated that this category is not necessarily specific to mukbang, but would leave the concept open to interpretation by streamers within its guidelines.<ref name="polygon-eating">{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/7/11/12149446/twitch-social-eating-interview|title=Why eating and gaming is a thing on Twitch|website=Polygon|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=18 July 2016}}</ref> [[File:Jangpa's MukBang - Short arm octopus and pork belly MukBang.webm|thumb|'''Jangpa's MukBang - Short arm octopus and pork belly MukBang.webm''']]
== On Media Platforms ==
The popularity of mukbang has inspired different variations and adaptions of the "Eating Broadcasting" concept. This trend has continued to gain viewers, create stars, and profit, catching the interest of mainstream media both domestically and internationally. In South Korea, there was a drama called ''[[Let's Eat (TV series)|Let's Eat]]'' (Hangul: 식샤를 합시다; RR: Siksareul Habsida) that focused on people who were brought together due to their love of food. In the drama, the characters explore various restaurants and after each episode, the featured foods became a hot topic among young adult viewers. Viewers sought out these restaurants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kdramastars.com/articles/15816/20140214/let-s-eat-drama-creates-appetizing-dining-trend-among-singles.htm|title=“Let’s Eat” Drama Creates Appetizing Dining Trend Among Singles|first=|last=kdramastars.com|date=14 February 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
Broadcasting stations are looking to capitalize on this interest in other ways as well. Happy Together, a popular entertainment show in South Korea, has a segment where their celebrity guests will cook and then share their favorite dishes with the rest of the cast.<ref>http://ttonl.org/mukbang-presents-diversion-from-traditional-online-entertainment-2/</ref> JTBC, a South Korean general cable TV network is also looking to jump on the bandwagon with a new variety show in the works. They are planning on a food-centric variety show called ''[[We Will Eat Well|Girls Who Eat Well]]'' and are looking to cast girl group members from popular South Korean K-pop girl groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.soompi.com/2016/05/01/jtbc-announces-a-new-mukbang-show-featuring-girl-group-members/|title=JTBC Announces A New Mukbang Show Featuring Girl Group Members|first=K.|last=Zertuche|date=1 May 2016|publisher=}}</ref> Popular South Korean variety series ''[[Infinite Challenge]]'' has also showcased the phenomenon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kdramastars.com/articles/104321/20151110/infinite-challenge-jung-joon-ha-and-haha-develop-a-muk-bang-tour.htm|title=‘Infinite Challenge’ Jung Joon Ha and Haha Develop A Muk-bang Tour|first=|last=kdramastars.com|date=10 November 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
Mainstream media is not the only platform to showcase mukbang. For example, celebrities have done mukbang broadcasts as a CF to promote a food brand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allkpop.com/article/2015/06/karas-youngji-has-the-cutest-mukbang-show-for-popeyes|title=KARA's Youngji has the cutest 'mukbang' show for 'Popeyes' - allkpop.com|publisher=}}</ref>
Mukbang has also gained international interest as well. The popular YouTube series, Youtubers React, showed various YouTube stars reacting to the South Korean trend and ended with their own mini mukbang show.{{Cn|date=February 2018}}
== See also ==
* [[Food porn]] * [[Cooking show]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Nero (''Devil May Cry'')}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox video game character |name=Nero |image= NeroDevilMayCry5.png |caption= Nero as he appears in ''Devil May Cry 5'' |series=''[[Devil May Cry]]'' |firstgame= ''[[Devil May Cry 4]]'' (2008) |creator= [[Bingo Morihashi]] |artist= Tatsuya Yoshikawa |voiceactor={{ubl|'''English'''|[[Johnny Yong Bosch]] '''Japanese'''|[[Kaito Ishikawa]] (''Devil May Cry 4: Special Edition'', ''Devil May Cry 5'')}} |motionactor= Johnny Yong Bosch (''Devil May Cry 4'')
Karlo Baker (''Devil May Cry 5'') }} {{nihongo|'''Nero'''|ネロ|lead=yes}} is a [[fictional character]] and one of the main [[protagonists]] of the ''[[Devil May Cry]]'' [[video game]] series, which was created and published by [[Capcom]]. He first appeared in ''[[Devil May Cry 4]]'' in 2008. Nero is a teenager working for the Order of the Sword; he uses his devil powers inherited from [[Characters of Devil May Cry#Sparda|Sparda]] to hunt enemies. In ''Devil May Cry 4'', Nero meets a demon hunter named [[Dante (Devil May Cry)|Dante]], the series' primary protagonist, to whom he learns he is related. Nero will return as one of the primary protagonists in the upcoming sequel, ''[[Devil May Cry 5]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesradar.com/devil-may-cry-5s-coming-in-spring-2019-and-it-stars-nero-dante-and-a-wise-talking-mechanic/|title=Devil May Cry 5's coming in spring 2019 and it stars Nero, Dante, and a wise-talking mechanic|publisher=GamesRadar+|author=Connor Sheridan|date=10 June 2018|accessdate=20 June 2018}} Nero was created by [[Bingo Morihashi]] and designed by Tatsuya Yoshikawa, who wanted to make the character fit into the world while contrasting him with Dante. The character was redesigned for ''Devil May Cry 5'' to establish his relationship with Dante's father Sparda and Dante's brother [[Vergil (Devil May Cry)|Vergil]] based on their multiple physical similarities. Nero is voiced by [[Johnny Yong Bosch]] in English and [[Kaito Ishikawa]] in Japanese. Critical reception to Nero has been mostly positive. While game journalists found that fans would miss playing as Dante during Nero's debut, his personality and abilities would be found as appealing. His new look and actions in the upcoming ''Devil May Cry 5'' have also been praised by critics. ==Creation and concept== Nero was created by the Capcom staff as a new protagonist who would develop across the ''Devil May Cry'' series because Dante had become stronger with each game. Nero was created as a weak character who develops new powers in the story until he reaches Dante's level. This was mostly done through his "Devil Bringer" ability, which makes him stand out. Another reason for Nero's introduction was to attract new gamers to the franchise.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesradar.com/devil-may-cry-4-interview-the-men-behind-the-mayhem/4/|title=Devil May Cry 4 interview - the men behind the mayhem|publisher=GamesRadar|accessdate=June 22, 2018}} The Devil Bringer was originally suited to be part of Dante's mechanics, but the staff found the games would be more interesting if a character who cannot transform into a demon would develop a demon arm. In the making of the game, Capcom wished to keep Nero's traits, except that Kyrie is his love interest, under wraps.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2007/10/interview-hiroy/|title=INTERVIEW: HIROYUKI KOBAYASHI TALKS DEVIL MAY CRY 4 STORYLINE|publisher=Wired|accessdate=June 23, 2018}} Bingo Morihashi was inspired to write Nero's story by the writings of late manga artist [[Ramo Nakajima]] in the series ''[[Amagasaki City]]''; "I love you, so I protect the city you love". Love is the focus of the ''Devil May Cry'' series; ''Devil May Cry 4'' focuses on Nero's love for Kyrie. While making ''Devil May Cry 4'' a simple story similar to Hollywood movies involving a [[damsel in distress]], the staff were satisfied with the story because it also carried Morihashi's ideas well.{{cite book|title=Devil May Cry: 3142 Graphic Arts|publisher=Capcom, Udon Entertainment|year=2015|isbn=978-1927925485|pages=211}} Fearing negative feedback, as happened when [[Konami]]'s stealth game ''[[Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty]]'' introduced a new character, replacing protagonist [[Solid Snake]] with newcomer [[Raiden (Metal Gear)|Raiden]], producer [[Hiroyuki Kobayashi (producer)|Hiroyuki Kobayashi]] stated Capcom aimed to make Nero fun to play, even when compared to Dante; they said the team aimed to make him stronger at some point.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesradar.com/devil-may-cry-4-interview-the-men-behind-the-mayhem/5/|title=Devil May Cry 4 interview - the men behind the mayhem|publisher=GamesRadar|accessdate=June 22, 2018}} Kobayashi described Nero as "characteristically wild, quite immature, young, and very passionate. At the same time he is kind of a rebel."{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/devil-may-cry-4-interview|title=Devil May Cry 4|publisher=Eurogamer|accessdate=June 22, 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.li/czhbD|archivedate=February 21, 2013}} Capcom originally planned to name their new character after the French sculptor [[Auguste Rodin]], who created ''[[The Gates of Hell]]'' from ''[[Dante's Inferno]]''. This work is referenced in ''Devil May Cry 4''; it causes demons to spawn within the human world. The Capcom team, however, later wanted a simpler name similar to the ones from Dante and Vergil. Writer Morihashi Bingo persuaded the staff to use the name Nero from the [[Nero|Roman emperor with the same name]]; he said the similarities between Nero and the name of Vergil's alter-ego [[Nero Angelo]] were coincidental and there is no connection between these two characters. Most of Nero's moves were named after casino terms, which Morihashi believed would fit with the character's personality. ===Design=== Nero was designed by Tatsuya Yoshikawa who did research for the entire ''Devil May Cry'' series when designing the new main character. Yoshikawa was satisfied with Nero's appearance and he believes he fits the ''Devil May Cry'' world.{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/previews/devil-cry-4_2?pager.offset=3|title=Devil May Cry 4|publisher=1UP.com|accessdate=22 June 2018|archivedate=October 24, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103190454/http://www.1up.com/previews/devil-cry-4_2?pager.offset=3}} Nero's physical appearance underwent several changes during the development of ''Devil May Cry 4''; early designs looked more like Vergil until the final design that resembled Dante.{{cite web|url=https://www.ricedigital.co.uk/devil-may-cry-3124-artbook-review/|title=Devil May Cry 3124 Artbook Review (Book)|publisher=Rice Digital|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} Capcom wanted to balance the traits between Nero and Dante, the game's two playable characters. While Nero was created to be weak due to his young age, Dante comes across as a more experienced person based on his previous works. Existing fans would be pleased by Dante's characterization and would stop playing as Nero.{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/previews/devil-cry-4_2?pager.offset=1|title=Devil May Cry 4|publisher=1UP.com|accessdate=22 June 2018|archivedate=October 31, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103190600/http://www.1up.com/previews/devil-cry-4_2?pager.offset=1}} Capcom had planned ideas for another ''Devil May Cry'' game, in which Nero would return and possibly team up with Dante. The company, however, first expected to see the fan response to ''Devil May Cry 4''.{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/previews/devil-cry-4_2?pager.offset=2|title=Devil May Cry 4|publisher=1UP.com|accessdate=22 June 2018|archivedate=October 31, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103190116/http://www.1up.com/previews/devil-cry-4_2?pager.offset=2}} Yoshikawa also created another devil transformation, the Devil Trigger, for Nero. Unlike Dante's transformation that makes him look like a devil, Nero's Devil Trigger generates a creature situated behind his back. The one that did not appear in the game turned Nero into a demon like Dante. Nero's hood covers one eye as a form of symbolism, which was left up to the fans. Yoshikawa wanted to incorporate this into the game and hoped to make it into a figurine, but this was not possible.{{cite book|title=Devil May Cry 4 Devil's Material Collection Art Book|publisher=Capcom|isbn=978-4862331854|year=2008|page=31}} Nero's redesign for ''Devil May Cry 5'' was intended to contrast with Dante's older look.{{cite web|url=http://gearnuke.com/devil-may-cry-5-interview-neros-lineage-design/|title=Devil May Cry 5 Director confirms Nero’s lineage and reason for new design|publisher=Gearnuke|author=Danial Arshad Khan|date=16 June 2018|accessdate=20 June 2018}} Capcom used an older incarnation of Nero so he would be "at the top of his game in body and mind".{{cite web |url= http://www.siliconera.com/2018/07/18/devil-may-cry-5-devs-on-balancing-photorealism-with-action-the-mystery-3rd-hero-more |title= Devil May Cry 5 Devs On Balancing Photorealism With Action, The Mystery 3rd Hero, More |publisher= Siliconera |date= July 18, 2018 |accessdate= July 18, 2018}} Because the graphics of the game are meant to be as realistic as possible, Nero's face was modeled after an actor named Karlo Baker.{{cite web|url=https://www.dailystar.co.uk/tech/gaming/682955/Devil-May-Cry-5-Nero-Dante-DMC-News-2019-Release-Date-pegi-Devil-Trigger-Updates-August-13|title=Devil May Cry 5: Nero, Dante, new characters, 18+ rating and 2019 release date news reveal|publisher=Daily Star|accessdate=August 13, 2018}} Fans of the series speculated whether Nero was related to Dante or Vergil, as in ''Devil May Cry 4''. Nero is said to be a descendant of Sparda, Dante's and Vergil's father, based on their similarities and Nero's power up, the Devil Trigger, which makes him look like Vergil's devil form. In June 2018, Capcom confirmed Nero is Vergil's son.{{cite web |url= https://us.blastingnews.com/gaming/2018/06/devil-may-cry-5-director-confirms-that-vergil-is-neros-father-possible-release-date-002630961.html |title='Devil May Cry 5' director confirms that Vergil is Nero's father; possible release date |publisher= Blasting News |author=Jane Flowers |date=19 June 2018 |accessdate= 20 June 2018}} Replacing his lost Devil Bringer, Capcom added Nero's prosthetic arm Devil Breaker, which will be important for the use of the character in combat.{{cite web |url= https://www.reddit.com/r/DevilMayCry/comments/8rjw7k/full_translation_of_famitsu_interview |title= Full translation of Famitsu interview |publisher= Reddit.com |accessdate= 22 June 2018}} Players who purchase the Deluxe Edition of ''Devil May Cry'' will receive four Devil Breaker weapons for Nero, including a Mega Buster based on ''[[Mega Man 11]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2018/09/19/devil-may-cry-5-shows-off-trish-lady-v-and-neros-mega-buster/|title=Devil May Cry 5 Shows Off Trish, Lady, V, And Nero’s Mega Buster|publisher=Siliconera|accessdate=September 20, 2018}} ===Voice actors=== [[File:Johnny Yong Bosch.jpg|thumb|221x221px|[[Johnny Yong Bosch]] voices Nero.]] Nero was voiced by [[Johnny Yong Bosch]]; while having played many characters—he enjoyed playing [[Ichigo Kurosaki]] from ''[[Bleach (manga)|Bleach]]'' and [[Vash the Stampede]] from ''[[Trigun]]''—Bosch felt Nero became his favorite. The actor stated that Nero was one of his favorite characters he has ever worked because of his story and because he went to Japan to do the [[motion capture]] for Nero.{{cite web |url= http://www.halfkorean.com/?page_id=379 |title= Interview with Johnny Yong Bosch |publisher= HalfKorean.com |accessdate= June 22, 2018}} In the Japanese version of ''Devil May Cry 4: Special Edition'', an updated version of the original ''Devil May Cry 4'', Nero was given a Japanese actor; [[Kaito Ishikawa]].{{cite web|url=http://www.behindthevoiceactors.com/Kaito-Ishikawa/|title=Kaito Ishikawa|publisher=Behind the Voice Actors|accessdate=June 22, 2018}} When dubbing the character, Ishikawa tried following Bosch's work so he could understand Nero's personality but he found this difficult because he did not know English. While Ishikawa had no previous experience with the series before working in ''Special Edition'', his friends gave him a positive outlook at it. During the recording of the series, Ishikawa met Dante's Japanese voice actor, [[Toshiyuki Morikawa]], with whom he interacted many times and helped him to understand the franchise. As he worked, Ishikawa gained a greater understanding of the game because it was translated in Japanese, which might attract more fans and was grateful for the experience.{{cite web|url=https://animeanime.jp/article/2015/06/29/23905.html|title=「デビル メイ クライ 4 スペシャルエディション」森川智之、石川界人インタビュー 遂に登場した日本語ボイス|publisher=Anime Anime|accessdate=June 25, 2018}} Ishikawa said Nero is a character who encompasses the "naughty young boy" that everyone has experienced being. He noted Nero's interactions with the enemies show a big contrast between his and Dante's characterization. Of the two main characters, Ishikawa said he believed Nero is taking his own path rather than following Dante's steps; he enjoyed the relationship between the two characters, which he took into account when recording the game. He decided to "cheer" on Nero for trying to act stylishly when facing his enemies, unlike Dante, whom he took notes from seeing Morikawa's work.{{cite web|url=https://www.famitsu.com/news/201507/03082422.html|title=『デビル メイ クライ 4 SE』森川智之さんと石川界人さんがダンテとネロを語る！|publisher=Famitsu|accessdate=June 30, 2018}} ==Appearances== In the fourth installment of the ''[[Devil May Cry]]'' series, having never knew his father, Nero's nature as Vergil's son begins to manifest when he injured himself protecting his childhood friend Kyrie from a pack of demons.{{cite web|url=https://www.destructoid.com/let-s-discuss-devil-may-cry-4-319342.phtml|title=Let's discuss Devil May Cry 4|publisher=Destructoid|author=Voltech|date=8 November 2015|accessdate=20 June 2018}} Later while attending a mass at the Order of the Sword, Nero's injured arm mutated into the Devil Bringer as the result of seeing Kyrie endangered when Dante appeared and killed their religious leader Santus and what he learned were demons dressed as Order acolytes. As he made a reputation as a lone wolf, Nero is given a mission to find and capture Dante.{{cite video game|title=Devil May Cry 4|publisher=Capcom|year=2008|developer=Capcom|quote='''Nero:''' Guy just came from Hell, he's gotta hit up a couple tourist sites. /'''Credo:''' You jest so lightly in a time of crisis? You must capture him.}} During his journey, Nero learns that the influx of demons on the island were arranged by Sanctus and learns of his resurrect as a demon by the Order's scientist Agnus, who developed demons from reverse engineering the remains of Nelo Angelo and Vergil's Devil Arms sword {{nihongo|Yamato|閻魔刀}}. Nero escaped death as Yamato sensed its master blood in Nero, fully awakening his powers while revealing him as a descendant of Sparda. This revelation convinces Sanctus into using Kyrie as bait to force Nero into assuming the role he intended Dante in animating the Savior colossus he created to wipe out all the demons and create a new utopia after destroying the world. But Dante sabotages Sanctus's plans and frees Nero so he can save Kyrie and destroy both Sanctus and the Savior.{{cite video game|title=Devil May Cry 4|publisher=Capcom|year=2008|quote='''Sanctus:''' We had originally intended Dante to form the Savior's core. Perhaps it would have been wise to adhere to that choice. /'''Nero''': Too late for regrets. Now release Kyrie!|developer=Capcom}} Despite the two being ignorant of their familial ties, Nero and Dante part on good terms with the latter allowing Nero to keep Yamato.{{cite video game|title=Devil May Cry 4|publisher=Capcom|year=2008|quote='''Dante:''' Keep it. / '''Nero:''' What...? I thought this meant a lot to you...? / '''Dante:''' That's the only kind of gift worth giving. I want to entrust it to you, and so I am. What you do from here is your call.|developer=Capcom}} A ''Devil May Cry 4'' novel by Bingo Morihashi expands Nero's background; he was found as a baby in Fortuna and was bullied by other children who claimed his mother was a prostitute. Nero was taken by Credo and Kyrie's family, and later joined the [[Order of the Sword]] to defeat demons, though Nero often worked alone. During the main story, Dante states he has fun interacting with Nero because Nero reminds him of his brother Vergil but cannot understand their connection.{{cite web|url=http://www.capcom-fc.com/devil4column/2009/04/_deadly_fortune.html|title=デビルメイクライ４ -Deadly Fortune-1|publisher=Capcom|language=Japanese|accessdate=May 2, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.capcom-fc.com/devil4column/2009/07/_deadly_fortune_1.html |title=デビルメイクライ４ -Deadly Fortune-2 |publisher=Capcom |language=Japanese |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602104915/http://www.capcom-fc.com/devil4column/2009/07/_deadly_fortune_1.html |archivedate= 2 June 2013 |df= }} In June 2018, Capcom confirmed Nero's father is Vergil. Nero will be one of the main protagonists of the upcoming game ''[[Devil May Cry 5]]''; he is depicted as being older than in the previous game and having lost his demonic arm, he wears a prosthetic arm to fight. Nero is shown to be a member of the mobile branch of Dante's "Devil May Cry" business and is working alongside a woman named Nico.{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/06/10/devi-may-cry-5-gives-dante-some-youtuber-swagger-and-a-robot-arm/|title=Devil May Cry 5 gives Nero some YouTuber swagger and a robot arm|publisher=Venture Beat|author=Stephanie Chan|date=10 June 2018|accessdate=20 June 2018}} Nero was also planned to appear in the [[fighting game]] ''[[Tatsunoko vs. Capcom]]'' but he was not available due to time constraints.{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2009/05/17/these-characters-didnt-make-the-tatsunoko-vs-capcom-cut/|title=These Characters Didn’t Make The Tatsunoko vs. Capcom Cut|publisher=Siliconera|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} He is mentioned in ''[[Marvel vs. Capcom 3]]'' by [[Deadpool]] while interacting with Dante.{{cite video game|title=Marvel vs. Capcom 3: Fate of Two Worlds|publisher=Capcom|year=2011|quote='''Deadpool:''' Next time, maybe you should let Nero do your fightin', skippy.|developer=Capcom}} In the fighting game ''[[Street Fighter V]]'', Nero's original appearance serves an alternate design for Ed.{{cite web|url=https://www.dualshockers.com/street-fighter-v-getting-devil-may-cry-costumes-updated-survival-mode/|title=Street Fighter V Getting Devil May Cry Costumes, Updated Survival Mode and More|publisher=Dual Shockers|accessdate=June 27, 2018}} ==Reception== [[File:Nero (Devil May Cry).jpg|thumb|right|Capcom stated fan response to Nero's ''Devil May Cry 4'' appearance has been positive.]] Nero has received many reviews from video game critics. Since his introduction in a demo, [[GameSpot]] felt the character would appeal to the series' fans, although Dante was more popular within the fandom.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/e3-07-devil-may-cry-4-hands-on-the-return-of-dante/1100-6169936/|title=E3 07: Devil May Cry 4 Hands-On - The Return of Dante|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=June 22, 2018}} Dante's replacement with Nero as the new main character was the subject of controversy within the fandom; ''GameAxis Unwired'' expected he would play similarly to Dante and that his Devil Bringer power would satisfy newcomers.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=sOoDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA20&dq=nero+devil+may+cry&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjz_fCmrOjbAhXFlJAKHR_BA-0QuwUIOjAC#v=onepage&q=nero%20devil%20may%20cry&f=false|date=July 2007|pages=20–21|title=Game Axis Unwired|publisher=SPH Magazines|accessdate=June 22, 2018}} Nero's gamplay style was praised by [[IGN]], which said he "strike[s] the right tone of gravity and sarcasm".{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/02/04/devil-may-cry-4-review-2?page=4|title=Devil May Cry 4 Review|publisher=[[IGN]]|author=Jeff Haynes|date=4 February 2008|accessdate=21 June 2018}} [[Capsule Monster]] labeled Nero as "our anti-hero with a heart" and enjoyed the character's mechanics as much as Dante's.{{cite web|url=http://www.capsulecomputers.com.au/devil-may-cry-4-special-edition-review/|title=Devil May Cry 4: Special Edition Review|publisher=Capsule Monsters|author=|date=|accessdate=22 June 2018}} Despite finding Nero a likable character due to his personality, GameSpot said players would also be pleased with the switch between Nero and Dante as ''Devil May Cry 4'' progresses. [[Den of Geek]] noted that while his debut might have surprised fans of Dante, his similar appearance and distinctive style might appeal to them.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/devil-may-cry-4-special-edition-review/1900-6416173/|title=Devil May Cry 4: Special Edition Review|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=June 22, 2018}} [[GameSpy]] described his combat by saying, "He has a fuel injector built in, so that he can 'rev' up his blade for charged attacks".{{cite web|url=http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/devil-may-cry-4/843481p1.html|title=Devil May Cry 4 is one of early 2008's hottest titles|publisher=[[GameSpy]]|author=Sterling McGarvey|date=3 January 2008|accessdate=21 June 2018}} [[US Gamer]] noted that despite Nero being one of the easiest characters from ''Special Edition'' to use, his combat still provides depth and that defeating the bosses was far more challenging using Nero than using Dante.{{cite web|url=https://www.usgamer.net/articles/devil-may-cry-4-special-edition-xbox-one-review-in-the-details|title=Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition Xbox One Review: In the Details|publisher=[[US Gamer]]|accessdate=22 June 2018}} While noting similarities between Nero and Dante, Metro said the former's other skills make him unique due to his swordsmanship and Devil Bringer.{{cite web|url=https://metro.co.uk/2015/06/30/devil-may-cry-4-special-edition-review-the-real-dante-5272896/|title=Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition review – the real Dante|publisher=Metro|accessdate=30 June 2018}} IGN also listed the Devil Bringer as the ninth-best weapon in the ''Devil May Cry'' series because Nero can attack any kind of enemy with his arm.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/videos/2013/01/22/dmc-top-10-devil-may-cry-weapons|title=DMC: DEVIL MAY CRY - TOP 10 DEVIL MAY CRY WEAPONS|publisher=IGN|accessdate=30 June 2018}} Dual Shockers enjoyed Nero's combat, which it said added new depth to the series because it is different from Dante's. The website, however, dismissed Nero's story, finding it unappealing.{{cite web|url=http://www.dualshockers.com/2013/07/22/then-and-now-the-devil-may-cry-series/|publisher=Dual Shockers|accessdate=30 June 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.li/yMdO8#selection-1737.251-1737.341|archivedate=May 4, 2015}} Capcom said it would not make a bad protagonist similar to that of ''Metal Gear Solid 2''. GameZone found Nero likable based on his actions in the plot and his powers.{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r28090.htm|title=Devil May Cry 4|publisher=Game Zone|archiveurl=http://archive.li/4O0zc#selection-625.0-628.0|archivedate=February 25, 2013|accessdate=June 22, 2018}} [[Game Informer]] agreed with GameZone, stating that Nero is as likable as Dante because he "lives up to his legacy".{{cite web|url=http://gameinformer.com/Games/Review/200803/R08.0205.1105.44993.htm|title=Devil May Cry 4 Review|publisher=Game Informer|archiveurl=http://archive.li/8ZXma#selection-1055.470-1055.574|archivedate=February 24, 2014|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]'' was more critical about his introduction because he replaced Dante while comparing him to ''[[God of War (franchise)|God of War]]'' protagonist [[Kratos (God of War)|Kratos]] based on personality traits that make him unlikable. Despite finding Nero's improvements in abilities less enjoyable, ''Edge'' still found that players will still find Dante more appealing in the progress of the story.{{cite web|url=http://www.edge-online.com/review/devil-may-cry-4-review/|title=Devil May Cry 4 Review|publisher=Edge|archiveurl=https://archive.is/rO3nH|archivedate=January 15, 2013|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} In the book ''[[1001 Video Games You Must Play Before You Die]]'', the author said the change to Nero from Dante was an attempt to please new gamers to the franchise because Nero performs simpler moves than Dante, who the writer said many players might have found boring due to the amount of moves and apparent decrease of sales in the series. The book describes Nero as a "a dead ringer" with moves similar to those of Kratos.{{cite book|title=1001 Video Games You Must Play Before You Die|publisher=Universe Publishing|year=2010|isbn=978-0-7893-2090-2|url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=olpPoAswgHoC&pg=PT1601&dq=nero+devil+may+cry&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUtajuhvLbAhXFhpAKHSlEBFwQuwUIWzAH#v=onepage&q=nero%20devil%20may%20cry&f=false|chapter=Devil May Cry 4|author=Mott, Tony}} Bosch's voice acting in the English-language version was also praised by GameZone for the way he portrays Nero, with GameSpot agreeing, calling Bosch's work "superb acting makes for one of the most appealing new game characters to be introduced in some time".{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/devil-may-cry-4-review/1900-6185608/|title=Devil May Cry 4 Review|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=June 26, 2018}} Reaction to Nero's upcoming role in ''Devil May Cry 5'' has been mostly positive. [[GamesRadar]] found Nero's actions in the ''Devil May Cry 5'' trailer appealing due to the way his character engages demons.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesradar.com/devil-may-cry-5-release-date-trailer-gameplay-details-and-more/|title=Devil May Cry 5 release date, trailer, gameplay details and more|publisher=[[GamesRadar]]|author=Bradley, Alab|accessdate=21 June 2018}} While joking about Nero's new look, ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' enjoyed his actions in the trailer.{{cite web|url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/06/10/software-shows-off-new-samurai-game-sekiro-shadows-die-twice-7620680/|title=From Software shows off new samurai game Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice|publisher=Metro|author=|accessdate=30 June 2018}} IGN criticized Nero's appearance in ''Devil May Cry 5'', comparing it to the redesigned version of Dante by [[Ninja Theory]] as a desperate, failed attempt to appeal to gamers during the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2018]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/06/15/e3-2018-opinion-devil-may-cry-5-and-crackdown-3-are-suffering-from-a-similar-identity-crisis|title=E3 2018: OPINION: DEVIL MAY CRY 5 AND CRACKDOWN 3 ARE SUFFERING FROM A SIMILAR IDENTITY CRISIS|publisher=[[IGN]]|author=|accessdate=22 June 2018}} Machitery Okabe from [[Capcom]], however, stated the response from gamers to Nero's new appearance was positive.{{cite web|url=https://www.hobbyconsolas.com/noticias/director-devil-may-cry-5-habla-nuevo-diseno-nero-265107|title=El director de Devil May Cry 5 habla del nuevo diseño de Nero|publisher=[[Hobby Consolas]]|author=|accessdate=22 June 2018}} Despite a confusing scene in the trailer in which it appears Vergil cuts Nero's arm, [[Kotaku]] was looking forward for the return of the three main characters—Dante, Vergil and Nero—in the game based on the preview.{{cite web|url=https://kotaku.com/devil-may-cry-5-announced-for-next-year-1826713438|title=Devil May Cry 5 Is Coming Next Year|publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=June 22, 2018}} Another Kokatu writer praised Nero's new costume and his metallic arm.{{cite web|url=https://kotaku.com/the-best-video-game-fashion-from-e3-2018-1826843507|title=The Best Video Game Fashion From E3 2018|publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=July 24, 2018}} Daily Star found the character likable based on his personality which reminded him on the comic superhero [[Spider-man]].{{cite web|url=https://www.dailystar.co.uk/tech/gaming/682955/Devil-May-Cry-5-Nero-Dante-DMC-News-2019-Release-Date-Devil-Trigger-Updates-September-9|title=Devil May Cry 5 Is An Effortlessly Cool Masterclass In Hack N Slash|publisher=Daily Star|accessdate=September 23, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/12/18/devil-may-cry-4-nero-preview|title=Devil May Cry 4 Nero Preview|publisher=[[IGN]]|author=Jeff Haynes|date=17 December 2007|accessdate=21 June 2018}} {{portal bar|2000s|Fictional characters|Japan|Speculative fiction|Video games}} {{Devil May Cry series}} {{Megami Tensei series}} [[Category:2008 introductions]] [[Category:Capcom characters]] characters with accelerated healing]] [[Category:Fictional characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Fictional half-demons]] [[Category:Fictional demon hunters]] [[Category:Fictional hunters in
